1.content:
Thick raindrops pelted Trevor through the branches he attempted to use as a shield. They were too bare, with few remaining leaves clinging despite the lashing of the wind. Considering the distance of the lodge across the clearing, a clearing with deep valleys that would be now filled with streams of water gushing from the saturated soil of the hills, he cursed his decision to leave his jacket in the car. The nippy breeze earlier in the day hadn't deterred him from his errand. Neither had the call for storms. Trevor didn't mind either, separately. The mix of the suddenly-dropped temperature, the sleeting rain, and near-complete black, however, forced thoughts of returning to his car. Even that would take effort with the seventy-mile-an-hour winds the weatherman had predicted appearing to be upon him and his car a couple of city blocks away. If he had still been in the city, that is.

But she was there, in the lodge, escaping him. Escaping them. He couldn't allow it.
1.title: Trevor: the decision pt 1

Eliza Browning sits in the lodge on a wicker seat, staring out the rain drop covered window.

I should do something, not just sit here. I should have a shower, look at my hair! It hasn't been this greasy since I spent a week with my sister. Get up, Eliza. Get up. GET UP!

Finally listening to her inner voice, Eliza stands up. She walks over to the front door and checks that it's locked.

Clump.

She freezes.

Clump. Clump.

Starting to shake, she turns towards the windows. A shadow appears to move past them, but it's hard to tell. It's so dark. She darts over to the unlit fire and grabs the poker, gripping it close to her chest.

Knock-knock.

Eliza lets out a terrified scream. "No! Can't I ever be free!"

Knock-knock.

Hang on...only one person knows I'm here, and she promised not to come. What does that mean??? Surely they wouldn't have been able to get it out of her?

An awful thought comes into her head: torture.

Knock-knock.

Taking a deep breath, Eliza walks back over to the door and reaches toward the chain with a quivering hand. She pulls it off, and tightens her hold on the poker at the same time. This time I won't be so submissive.

111122.content:
Tears streamed down the red-haired girl's eyes. "I'm so sorry Eliza, I -- "

"Come on, move!" Ginny was shoved viciously through the threshold by a large man. She fell into Eliza, and Eliza -- on instinct -- tried to catch her with free hand. Ginny squeaked as they both tumbled to the ground, the fire poker jostled away. In that same instant the man was next to her and had grabbed Eliza's arm, but not to steady her, but to lift her up and bring her face to face with him.

"I think you have something that belongs to me," he hissed, his eyes boring threateningly into hers. Ginny scrambled from the floor at his feet, reaching for the poker, but he gave her a vicious kick to the ribs. She let out a loud cry.

Misty ran to the room, her eyes wide in alarm. When she saw what was happening, she gasped and took an involuntary step back. She didn't truly understand why this was happening. She was shocked, but that didn't stop her from diving for the weapon lying on the ground. The man saw, and roughly pushed Eliza away. She landed on top of Ginny, and the crush of her weight caused the air to whoosh painfully from the young girl's lungs.

But Misty wasn't fast enough, and the man was closer. He grabbed the fire poker, and with which seemed like no effort at all, swung it at her.

Misty ducked away, and the poker came just inches from her face. It was all so sudden that she had no time to think or feel frightened. It was all on instinct. The man was angry, and with each swing it was visible. His hard face was contorted in rage, and as he kept missing, he began to yell in fury.

But then, finally, the dance of swinging and dodging ended. He swung forcefully, and Misty wasn't fast enough. The hooked side made contact with her arm, and she cried in shock, her arm searing with pain.

She stumbled back, her hand reaching up and gripping her arm. Her bent over and grimaced against the sting, and when she peered through the gaps of the blond hair now fallen in her face, saw the man had switched the poker in his other hand and was advancing on her.

She had no time to react, and he gripped the front of her blouse with his fist and pushed her up against the wall. "Want to play games little girl?" he snarled, his face inches from her. "'Cause I can play games. We can keep doing this all night if you want, until your friend there tells me where she's hiding the boy."

Eliza and Ginny were up now. Misty could see Ginny was creeping towards the door to the den were the phone was, and Eliza had made her way to the kitchen counter, her hand slowly reaching out to the block with the knives. Misty knew her friend would never use one, and that it was only for self defense if he tried to attack her.

Trevor was now arousing from where he passed out on the couch. The man, still gripping her shirt, twisted his head to glance through the doorway that led to the den. Inside, the boy was struggling to sit up, groggy and dazed. "Ow, my head..."

The man smiled deviously. "Ah, there he is."

Misty was dragged along with him, and she was shocked at his alarming strength. She was lucky he hadn't just finished her off when he pinned her against the wall.

She started struggling to try to get free of the man's grip, and tried scratching at his hands with her with her nails. However, she might as well have been trying to scratch a rock, as all she did was damage her own nails. His skin was tough, and he took no notice of her efforts to break free. Misty started to despair. She just couldn't let the man get to Trevor, but could she do? Ginny was already out of the room and couldn't see what was happening, while Eliza had picked up a large knife but was simply standing frozen to the spot.

All of a sudden, the door of the lodge burst open and a muscular young man rushed in, looking around wildly. Misty took one look at him and yelled out in shock. "James?? What are you doing here!?" James took no notice, but stared coldly at the man dragging Misty and said in a hard voice, "Let them go, Seth."

Seth turned around and grinned. "So you're here, James? Sorry, I can't do that. Try and stop me." With that, he rushed straight at James, while Misty watched in horror from the floor.

111211.content:
Eliza spun around to stare at the broken window, her heart racing.

"What is it Eliza?" asked Robyn worriedly. She was at her friend's side in an instant.

"I, I thought..." The girl's eyes were wide as she stared at, but as she glanced around, she couldn't see anything in the dark gloom. She thought she had seen a shadow in the trees. Was her mind just playing tricks on her? "Uh, nothing."

She turned away then, her mind and stomach reeling. The smell of Trevor's blood and the death she had just witnessed made her want to throw up and cry her eyes out, but she had to keep moving. It wasn't safe here. She needed to get away.

Robyn touched her arm gently and the two of them joined Luke and opened the back door cautiously. The man glanced out, assessing the darkness outside, and then nodded to them. The three of them quietly crept out and skirted the edge of the cabin, their eyes darting to the forest.

Eliza was crying silently now. Tears streaked down her face as if a faucet was suddenly turned on and broken so that it was impossible to turn off. One agonizing thought kept ringing in her mind: Trevor's dead... Trevor's dead... Trevor's dead....

Luke glanced back and saw Eliza. A sad look came on his face, but he did nothing else to comfort her. There was no use telling her that everything was going to be okay, because they all knew that that was unlikely.

Once they reached the far side of the house, Luke stopped. Rain was pelting down on them hard and Luke's long brown hair was plastered around his face, appearing black in the night. His clothes were soaked and now the girls could see the muscular build the see-through white shirt revealed. They didn't know him well, but they suddenly felt very safe with him.

"We can't go back to the car," he said matter-of-factly, his face grim. The girls already knew that. If anyone was waiting for them, they would be there.

"Then where can we go?" Robyn asked. She was shivering next to Eliza, for she too was soaked to the bone. The wind blew viciously through the trees, and Luke hoped that the weather would aid them in keeping them concealed.

"There's a cave near the mountain. It'll be safe there."

Eliza squinted in the night and spotted the loom of the large rocky hill above the trees. It was close, but it would take a long time to get there. "Do you think we can make it without them seeing us?"

Luke was still staring out at the mountain, lost in thought, "I don't know. But we have to try." He turned around to face the younger woman, her hair black because of the rain. "We can't go back in the house, but we need something to use to protect us. Do you have a garden shed nearby? Anything?"

Eliza nodded gravely. "Yes. I have a shovel inside that I think would work."

Robyn and Eliza watched Luke for a moment as the thought, and then he nodded. "Alright, show me too it,"

Eliza crept back a little and skirted a few dark evergreens. The three of them traveled deeper into the woods, their eyes straining in the darkness, until they reached a small shed. Luke pushed through and grabbed the handle. As quietly as he could, he pulled it open. It creaked, and the three of them clenched their teeth, but soon Luke had it open and stepped in.

It was dark and cramped, with pot and soil bags pilled on the ground. The man had to tip toe his way carefully around the things so not to hit one with his feet or trip. The girls were peeking through and watching him maneuver his way in. "The shovel is in the back next to the weed-whacker," Eliza hissed. Her hands clenched the side of the door and her ears and eyes were alert for any movement of noise around them.

Luke saw the shovel and exhaled in relief. He reached out and delicately grabbed it, careful not to hit it against anything. With as much care as if handling a new-born child, he held it and crept back out of the shed. Eliza silently shut the door behind him, and the three of them looked at the shovel in relief. It was short, but had a very strong wooden neck and a very sharp and hard shovel end. It was shaped like a pentagon, so the end was a definite point, perfect for defending yourself with. Luke held it closely, and he nodded to us and turned around to face the way of the mountain.

They hurried out, flanking the trees and trying to avoid the leafy ground as much as possible. If anyone was around, they didn't want the crunch of the leaves to reveal their position. They ran on in silence, their eyes flickering around them, alert for any sign of life. The wind howled by; covering their sound, and thunder clapped above. The three of them had never been so thankful for a storm in all their life. It seemed that the earth itself was on their side.

They were about twenty minute in and climbing a hill when they heard it. The wind had carried the sound to them, and the sky was still when the gun shot rang out. It was quiet and muffled though, and they knew that it was far away -- back at the house -- but they stopped and glanced back.

"What was--"

"A gun shot," Luke said, answering Robyn. He was staring the way they came, his shovel held firmly. Eliza's mind was reeling. Who would they be shooting at...?

"I don't know," said the man. Eliza realized she had asked it out loud. "But we can't stay standing here any longer." He lightly grabbed Eliza's arm, and steered her away. They continued their rush for escape, climbing higher until they reached the crest of the hill and glanced down.

Fields spread ahead of them, the moonlight illuminating the wide expanse of land. They had reached near the edge of the forest then, and were staring ahead of them nervously. They all knew that once they left, they would be exposed.

"We have to keep going. Only once we reach the cave can we be safe for the night."

The girls didn't say anything, but they thought the same. They made their way carefully down the large hill, and soon were skirting the first field. The rain was harder here, and the wind battered them painfully, sending chills down their spines. They felt miserable, but they kept pushing ahead, their quest giving them faith.

The moon had risen high in the sky when they were at their last field. Just a little farther and they would be at the base of the mountain where they would be sheltered by the trees again. Then they could begin searching for the cave entrance.

Suddenly, a light flashed in the corner of the travelers' eyes as lightening forked and struck a tree near them. A heartbeat later the sky clashed in thunder and the three of them jumped. Eliza felt as if her heart had leapt out of her chest.

"That was close," Robyn said while staring at the tree in fear. She hurried forward next to Luke's side. Eliza suspected that the girl liked Luke, but now wasn't a time to be thinking about crushes. Eliza hurried too, and soon they were walking side by side, Luke in the middle with the shovel.

At long last they reached the cover of the trees. Relief hung heavy over the three. Luke told the girls where he thought the cafe might have been, and they began to search for it together.

It was foolish for them to let their guard down -- to believe that they were safe. If they had been listening for the small snaps in the woods, and the silent crunch of leaves, then maybe they could have saved themselves. Maybe if they hadn't forgotten to hide behind trees and to watch the darkness around them they wouldn't be in the position they found themselves in. If Luke had reminded them to keep watch, or had not allowed Robyn to stray a little deeper in the woods, then maybe they might have noticed something was wrong. But they didn't and soon this happened.

"Okay, if I remember correctly, the cave should be near a large boulder. I think it was that way," he said, pointing left. They were deeper into the forest now and were facing the large hill and its sheer rocky face. Luke seemed to be more relaxed now that they were sheltered. The three of them had been traveling for about two hours. They were exhausted, and the only thought that must have been on their mind was to find the cave.

The girls followed Luke as he made his way through the trees. The ground here wasn't as heavy with leaves, since it was mostly pine and evergreens. The needles acted as soft cushions and made little noise as they treaded on them, but the branches were higher and the forest sparser. It gave little cover.

A few leaves could be found though, and most of them were deeper in. The wind had calmed as the storm was beginning to pass. The thunder clapped on in the distance, moving away from the mountain and the travelers. They though it a relief, but they shouldn't have. The wind and the rain and the storm no longer acted as a cover; protecting them from the enemy. It left them, and with it hope for concealment. Beside the black of the night, they were dangerously exposed to those who might have been in the woods with them.

Robyn straggled away from Luke and Eliza in her search for the cave. She didn't think she'd gone far. She could still see their silhouettes in the loom of the moon, ambling through the trees. She glanced away and searched the sheer face for any sign of the cave. She was only three minutes in searching when it happened.

Eliza had been with Luke, their voices quiet but not quite enough in the night.

"Why is it you helped us Luke?" Eliza asked. She was staring up at the man questioningly, but her eyes shone gratefully in the night. Luke was holding the shovel loosely, and was staring down at it contently.

"Because I too am on the run from them. I knew you brother, Eliza -- Mike. He told me that you were in trouble, and I decided to help you out. People like us got to stick together, you know."

Eliza nodded. She had grown fond of Luke, and was thankful for all his help. She trusted him completely now, and would travel to the ends of the earth with him if she had to.

"Thank you." she sighed. Luke looked at her and smiled. He opened his mouth to tell her that it was no problem when suddenly a gun shot rang out, extremely close.

It all happened so quickly. Eliza's heart jumped, along with Luke's as they snapped their heads around to the source of the noise, their eyes wide and their breath caught in terror.

In the loom of the trees they saw Robyn crumble to the ground. Her beautiful long red hair fell out of her face as she collapsed backwards. Time seemed to stand. In the moonlight, she looked like a dying angel. Her mouth and eyes were open in shock as the bullet made impact with her chest. In her last dying attempt, she sprawled out her hands to catch her fall, but the strength seemed to leave her and she hit the ground hard on her side. Her hair draped across her face delicately, and her slender hands rested on the ground next to her head. She looked like she was sleeping, but they both knew she was not. She was dead.

They stared in utter horror. Even Luke seemed immobile and surprised by the death. It was so unexpected.

No... no.... Eliza couldn't think straight. All that streamed through her shocked mind was that this was all just a terrible trick. She would blink and all this would be gone. This wasn't happening... it couldn't be happening....

Then three men stepped out of a cave in the mountain base a little ways ahead. A large boulder rested next to it. It was the place they were looking for that whole time -- the cave. The one place they thought they would be safe, and it turned out it was the exact place they wouldn't. Some of them had been waiting. How did they know they'd go there?

The man who killed Robyn turned his gun on them. Eliza panicked and dived for a nearby tree. Luke did the same, and the bullet flew by, it's bang ringing through the night.

"Get them!" The man ordered the other two, who were looking at him excitedly. They pulled out their guns and ran down the slanting ground towards them. Another gun shot rang out.

"Run!" Luke shouted to Eliza, pointing towards the forest behind them -- their only escape. Eliza bolted with him at her heels, running faster than they had ever ran before, fainting and zigzaging through the trees to avoid the bullets.

On they ran, running through the pain it their chest and the screaming of their tired legs. On they went, not looking back, dodging behind trees and running to the next. The gun shots kept coming, each one missing, until they suddenly stopped all together.

They didn't look back. They kept going and going, never pausing. Their breathing was heavy and labored, but they fought through the pain. They had to.

It felt like they had been running for hours when Eliza tripped on a root and fell, clutching her chest as she tried to steady her heart. Sobs broke out and there she stayed, not getting up. Luke stopped too, and crouched down next to her, murmuring words meant to comfort her. Their pursuers were long gone. They were deep in the woods, farther away from the mountain and beyond the fields. They were in the real forest, far away from civilization. They were safe, or at least they prayed they were.

"What do we do now?" Eliza asked through broken tears, her voice thick with pain and emotion. Luke looked down sympathetically at her, but shook his head.

"I don't know, but we can't give up. They'll just keep hunting us."

"Luke," she whispered, her eyes wide and sad, "Are we ever going to be safe?"

Luke looked away and at the dark walls of the forest surrounding him. They seemed full of shadows and menace. His eyes clouded, and as he spoke gravely, a new wistfulness came to him. "If we give up hope, then we never will. That will be when we are truly caught and killed. We must never lose faith, for faith is the only thing that can keep us alive now."
111211.title: The Fight for Survival

1112111.content:
After resting and catching their breath, Eliza and Luke continued through the forest. Without a compass it was hard to know which way to go. One thing they knew for sure though was to go away from the cave. Hopefully the forest would end soon and they would find themselves back at civilization.

They traveled in silence for a while. Cautious to make any noise in case they were still following them. Soon though, the storm subsided and they were able to tell that they weren't being followed.

"So you said you knew Mike?" Eliza asked Luke.

"Yeah. We met back at camp. He was my roommate and there was an instant bond. We always laughed and joked around. He told me a lot about you. Showed me pictures your parents sent. I have a brother your age and so we compared you two a lot. When we left for his first assignments we made a pact. We would always look out for each other and our siblings. Especially if anything was to happen to us."

Eliza hadn't gotten to know Mike that well so to hear someone else talk about him felt good. He was significantly older than she was and so by the time she was old enough to remember, their parents had already sent him to camp. She really only saw him on holidays and for a week or so during the summer. Other than that he usually stayed at camp. By the time she went to camp he was long gone and out in the world. She would receive letters from him every once in a while but she never knew where he was or what he was doing– just that he was alive. Until the day he wasn't.

She remembered the day clearly. The new term had started and the weather was still warm. She had been training hard that morning and when she had been dismissed for lunch, a large man (much like Luke) was standing outside the dining hall waiting for her. He was dressed unlike anyone else she had ever known to be there. Cautious, she held back for a moment. The man looked at his watch and then rested his hands on his hips impatiently. She was just able to make out the outline of a gun along his belt line. Not a good sign. Prepared for combat, she tentatively approached the man.

"Can I help you sir?"

"Are you Elizabeth Goode?"

"Yes but I got by Eliza."

"Detective Joseph Markowitz. Mind if we take a walk?"

She still wasn't sure why this man was here but something inside of her told her to trust him. "Okay. But I don't have that long for lunch so let's make it quick."

The two walked behind the dining hall and made their way towards the dock on the lake. "How well did you know your brother?"

"Not that well. I never really saw him." She was confused. What did Mike have to do with all this? "Why? What's going on?"

He looked down at the ground then back at her. His eyes were filled with sorrow and regret. "Eliza, Mike's dead."

She froze for a minute. Sure she didn't know him that well but he was still her brother. Greif started to well up inside her chest and soon the tears came. "What happened?" She asked with a sniffle.

"That's classified."

"Classified? CLASSIFIED?!" Eliza started screaming, rage now replacing the greif as she pushed . "He was my brother! You could have at least had the decency to tell me how he died!"

"I told you, I can't. You have to trust me though, if I could, I would."

She crumpled onto the dock crying. Why was she so emotional over the brother she barely knew? Against what Eliza would have thought characteristic of him, he sat down on the dock with her.

"I know I can never understand what you are going through but just know that I'm here to help." He pulled a business card out of his coat pocket and handed it to her. "There might be some people who come looking for you to tie up loose ends of your brother's. These people are dangerous so if you ever think that they're following you, call me." He had a sense of urgency in his voice.

He sat with her on the dock for a moment but then got up. "I have other business to attend to so I'll leave you to yours. Once again, if you ever feel you're in danger call me first."

And that is exactly what she had done. He had told her to meet him in Rosenberry, a town he and his team were currently using as a headquarters. She had been on her way there when the storm delayed her and forced her to rent the lodge. Now here she was trudging through a forest going towards who knows what with a man she had just met who supposedly knew her brother.

"Do you know what Mike was involved in at all?"

"No, but I've heard rumors. Nothing concrete though."

The two continued on for a while in silence. "I think we should rest here for the night."

"Don't you think we should take shifts keeping watch?"

"Sure, that sounds good." He examined her head to toe. "You rest first. You look you need it."

Without arguing Eliza laid down. A few moments later, once he was certain she was asleep. Luke wandered off into the forest. He get far until he met his contact.

"Wow Luke. I would have never taken you for an actor." The voice said out of nowhere. It startled him at first but he knew it was characteristic. Out of the corner of his eye he saw a figure emerge from the woods.

"Peter, nice to see you."

"Yeah, yeah. Let's cut to the chase." Peter said dismissively. "Does she know anything?"

"Doesn't seem like it. But she's also trained so who knows what secrets she's keeping."

Peter let out a sigh of disapproval. "Try harder." And with that he left.

"Oh, and try not to be so deadly with the attacks okay? Make them believable, not life-threatening. Okay?" Luke yelled towards Peter. Peter just waved him off. He returned to Eliza and after a couple hours woke her to take her shift.

The next morning the two headed off again in the same direction they had been traveling the night before. The clouds had cleared away overnight and so it was easier to get a sense of direction with the sun above their heads.

"Do you hear that?" Luke said.

Eliza paused for a second. "Cars." She realized. "We must be close to a town!"

They quickened their pace and soon were greeted by a "Welcome to Rosenberry" sign. Rosenberry. How perfect. Eliza thought to herself. "I know someone here who can help us." she told Luke.

They navigated through town. Detective Markowitz had given Eliza directions to his office but she had left them back in her car which was now abandoned at the lodge so she was left to follow them by memory.

"You know, it is really tragic how your brother died."

Eliza paused for a second. "How do you mean?"

"Being burned alive must have been brutal."

"That information is supposed to be confidential." She said. She looked up at Luke and instantly she saw a look of 'oops, I wasn't supposed to say that' in his eyes. Then it hit her, "You didn't meet my brother at camp." She thought back to Mike's letters. "I never remember him mentioning a Luke and plus, his roommate was named Stephen." She didn't know who Luke was but she knew one thing. She had to run.

111212.content:
"Guys." she said, her voice shaken.

"Huh?" Luke looked to her.

Robyn stopped in her tracks, Eliza's coat in her hands.

"There's someone outside. I saw something."

"Youre sure about this?" Luke, the stranger, was dead serious.

"What did you see? was it..."

"You wouldn't believe me if I told you, Robyn." In reality Eliza had caught more detail, than she ever wished she could. Right on the other side of the window she saw what appeared to be too large and too furry to be who she was hiding from. No, whoever was outside, was not a man, but some sort of beast or animal.

"No, it was large. Like a bear or something." But it couldn't of been. It was staring right into the window upright, like a human.

"Is she alright?" Luke asked Robyn, clearly reserving no time for Eliza and her crazy beast-bear siting.

"The winds are blowing 70 miles an hour Eliza." Robyn said slowly. "There are no bears hanging outside the lodge in these conditions."

Eliza swallowed.

"I saw what I saw."

"Yea, sure. I'm out of here." Luke hissed, feeling as though Eliza wasn't taking the initial situation seriously.

Yet, Luke was the only man at the lodge between the three of them. Eliza and Robyn exchanged glances at each other, debating whether or not it would be safer to leave with him, and in Eliza's case, confront the beast. Or, stick behind, as two defenseless women,and wait for the person they were fearing, to come find them. Luke said he was being followed. If it was the same person, that Eliza feared it to be, all they had was time before they were discovered here.

"We have to go, Eliza."Robyn said. "It's the best thing to do."

"But what about that THING out there?" Eliza whispered, weakly.

"Eliza, no one else saw it but you."

"That doesn't mean that it doesn't exist!"

Luke was halfway out the door. Frantic, Robyn grabbed Eliza's arm and dragged her behind her as she caught up with Luke.

"We're coming with you, Luke." Robyn said strongly, aggravated, that Luke was just going to leave the two of them behind so easily.

"At least one of you have come to your senses."

Robyn shook her head, putting her disproval of this man behind her, because he was the only man. She knew she couldn't be too picky.

The minute the three of them stepped outside, the wind nearly blew them back into the house.

"Jeese!" Luke said.

"I wasn't lying about that weather, you know." Eliza said, hiding behind Robyn.

"Yea, like i have reason to believe a hallucinating girl."

Robyn clenched her teeth, close to saying something offensive to defend Eliza.

The three moved slowly around the house, any farther from its walls and they'd probably blow away.

"What the..." Luke questioned what was up ahead.

Once the group turned the corner, it was clear. The silhouette of a large and dark being stood on the opposite side of the house. It stood on its hind legs, it carried...a pole?
No. A...
The pole in its arms was turned to point at the lead of the group.

"Aargh!" Luke yelled. But his voice wasn't even that loud against the sound of the blowing wind.
Robyn screamed and came to a halt behind Luke, who was now on his knees. He dropped to the ground, his shirt only moving from the strength of the wind.

"Robyn that's..."

"We have to get back inside." Robyn said, but it was easier said than done. She was frozen with fear. It was Eliza this time that had the strength to take Robyns hand and pull her, against the wind, back into the lodge.

the two of them rushed inside, failing to close the door behind them, as they escaped to the far side of the lodge. they dropped themselves behind the bar.

"I'm so sorry." Robyn said, on the verge of tears. "I just couldn't."

"I know, I know..just dont think about that." Eliza said but then she gasped.

"What? What's wrong?" Robyn's eyes were large and glossy.

"The door is still open." her voice cracked. "I didnt even close the door!"

"It's okay, it's okay. We'll close the door." Robyn looked at her. "We'll close it together okay?"

"Do you think we have enough time? Do you think that thing hasn't already circled the house by now?"

"Oh, I dont know Eliza, but either way..."

Robyn was right if they didnt close the door, or at least try to close the door, they'd encounter this thing that killed Luke. One way or another they were screwed if they didnt try.

The two of them crawled out from behind the bar. Once they got to their feet, Robyn grabbed onto Eliza's hand.

"Okay, lets do this nice and quietly..." Eliza's vioce trembled.

"But quickly!" Robyn charged towards the door, Eliza flying behind her.

Yet before her hand could hit the door. It swung open all the way, and slammed back onto the wall behind it, on the inside of the house.

The two women screamed, and dropped to the floor from the impact. Whether this impact was from the outside wind, or the shock, they weren't sure.

The silhouette of the large creature stood in the doorway.
The two girls started crying and holding each other tightly.
"wha...what is it?"

The creature had to duck to fit beneath the door. Actually it had to turn sideways as well, because it's width took up the entire frame. But, the minute it stepped into the light the girls were positive. A bear. A bear holding a shotgun.

"Oh my god," Robyn gasped. "A bear killed Luke."

"With a shotgun." Eliza specified.

"You think he's going to shoot us?" Robyn whispered hurriedly.

"The bear? Do you think he even knows what he's doing with it?"

"How could he? He's a bear." Robyn sounded manic as she contemplated this.

In the meantime, the bear stared at the two whimpering girls on the ground.
He, the bear, cleared his throat. The girls squeeled pathetically at the sound he made.

"So, no ones going to offer me something from the bar?"
It came out low, like a growl, or a very sore throat.

Robyn and Eliza looked at one another, to make sure that they both heard the same thing.

"Does anyone here speak any english?" It came out sarcastically from the bear, but he continued. "It's the only other language I know beside my own lingo.
"I've just started spanish...but I'm not that good at it yet."

When the girls stared at him blankly, he tried.

"Hablas ingles? I know you dont speak bear."

"Si." Robyn spit out, as though english really was her second language.
"I mean yes, yes, we're both American."

"We both speak english." Eliza clarified, hoping that this information would please him and keep him from shooting them. With a talking bear, she had no doubt now that he knew what he was doing with a gun.

"Well?" his voice was deep and threatening. "Than why hasnt anyone answered my first question?"

Eliza and Robyn have to stare at eachother for the question that they have both forgotten. How were they to remember his exact inquiry, when they were too busy trying to comprehend, the idea that a bear could be fluent in english.

The two of them shrug their shoulders pitifully. The expressions on their pale faces are desperately begging for mercy.

The bear sighs. "Humans." and shakes his head.
"No one is going to offer me something warm to drink?"

"Oh", the girls think, curious as to this bears intentions.

"Of course, of course!" Robyn crawls towards the bar, until she has the strength to push herself up off the hardwood floor.

The bears stares after her, unsure as to whether he is freaked out, or amused.
"You guys act like you haven't even evolved yet. Heck, I feel I've evolved more than you." He chuckles and hearty cough sounding chuckle, and then stops when he realizes Eliza, on the floor still, is not finding it funny. Her eyes are still wide and pleading. Still staring up at him, like a rodent to a human.

The bear snorts at this.
"Jeese, lighten the heck up."

"But..Mr. Bear... you just shot Luke."

"Mr. Bear! Mr. Bear!" he mocks in an unusually high snarl.

Eliza crosses her brow, not only afraid now, but offended too.

"You speak these words like you knew the guy."

Just then Robyn returns from the bar, a cup with hot chocolate and whip cream on top. Bears must like sweets, she assumed. They ate honey didn't they?

"Here...sir." she refrained from calling him Mr. Bear. Especially after witnessing the title fail with Eliza.

He stared over at the drink in her hand.

"What the...what is that?"

"Hot chocolate? there's whipped cream on top." Robyn states innocently.

"Lady, I'm a bear. I'd like a beer."

"Huh?"

"What, you've never had warm beer before?"

"No.."

"-Amatuer."

Robyn is silent. She turns away without commenting and rushes back to the bar to get this bear a real drink.

The bear turns back to Eliza.

"You didnt know Luke."

"How do you know?"

The animal growls.

"Cause you treated him like he was completely innocent the minute he walked into the lodge. If you knew the guy and what his intentions were, you wouldn't of have been so lax about letting him in."

"If you knew him you would've treated him like you're treating me. Like I'm a monster.
And why do I get this treatment? Because I'm a bear? Is that it?"

"Well, you did kill someone."

"Luke? and who do you suppose killed you're lover?"

"You?" Eliza squeaked

"NO, you..." The bear took a deep inhale. "Deep breaths" he reminded himselves.

"Luke killed him."

Eliza covered her mouth with her palm. Robyn was walking back with the bears drink, and had stopped in her tracks.

"It was so obvious too! He ran in right after he shot him.I dont know why you two didn't put the two and two together."

"But he looked so innocent." Robyn spoke.

"Well." The bear growled. "You can't always judge a book by it's cover...Hand me that drink, please."

Robyn walked up to the gigantic bear cautiously. She never in her life came this close to a bear, let alone, hand a beer to one.

"Thanks." he said, clearly not as fascinated nor fearful as she was with this exchange. He brought the mug up to his mouth and took a sip.
"Ooo thats hot, but good."

Robyn and Eliza took this opportunity to really calm down and breath. There really was no reason in fretting over what they had witnessed over the last half hour. Thinking about it would just drive them crazy.

"Wait..." The bear put down his mug on a nearby table and took a moment to listen.

"They're here now."

"Who?" Eliza said. She looked to Robyn for conformation. Robyn nodded, gravely. They both knew very well who it was.
111212.title: Eliza points out what or who is at the window

1112122.content:
The bear opened the door. A young Hispanic boy, no more than sixteen or seventeen, strolled into the house dripping water onto the floor. The girls were struck at once by his appearance; for starters, he was mind-bogglingly gorgeous. Robyn wasn't sure that such a face could even be human. But his eyes were a brilliant sapphire blue that, despite his aggrivated expression, was full of despair. That blue wasn't a normal eye color, of that Robyn was sure. He was tall and lean, but managed to fill out his clothes wonderfully.

Clay walked in and took off his coat. "Brrr!"

"I'm sorry, who are you?" Eliza asked.

"I'm Clay Hall." He put his coat on the rack by the door.

"Why are you here?" Robyn asked.

"To help keep you safe." He said it as a matter of fact, with no particular emotion at all. Eliza frowned and asked, "From what?"

Clay shook his head. "I'm sorry. I'd rather wait until the others get here to explain that."

"What others?" Robyn asked.

But Eliza moved forward to a spot on the floor right in front of him. "Look, I'm sure you're a great person, but I don't see how a teenage boy is going to protect us from anything. I'm sorry."

But he didn't seem bothered by it. A smug smile crept over his face. He'd identified a challenge. Somehow the look made him more attractive.

"Oh, you don't, do you?"

Eliza felt a lump in her throat. "No."

Clay nodded. He turned to the bear. Suddenly, his hands shot out, took the bear, and hoisted him over his head.

"HEY!!! We talked about this!" the bear griped.

Robyn smiled. "Okay, put him down. You're about to rip your shirt."

"What? No, I'm--oh, wait." He noticed how tight the fabric was around his arms. He put the bear back down gingerly. "Sorry, ol' boy. She made me."

Eliza gasped. "No, I did not!

Clay laughed. "I'm kidding."

The door flew into the living room. A large bald man stepped in wielding a metal rod. He stepped toward the girls.

"Oh, no you don't!" The bear ran at him. A roar rose from his throat. The bald man cracked him in the skull and stepped aside as he ran into the wall and fell to the floor. He looked at Clay and smiled.

"You think you can take me, little boy?" He laughed heartily. "I tell you what. I'll even give you the stick."

He tossed Clay the rod. Clay considered it for a moment and snapped it like a brittle twig.

"Nah. Don't need it." He swung with his right fist. The bald man's shirt bunched into a ball and moved forward, and he was pulled right into Clay's line of fire. The popping sound was incredible. The bald man was thrown back into the doorway. Several teeth fell out of his mouth.

Robyn's eyes were wide. "Nice work."

"Thank you, thank you." He wiped his hands on his jeans and stepped over to the bear. "Alright, let's get to the chair, Buddy."

He pulled him up by the arm and steadied him when he was on his feet. "Are you alright?"

"I'll have a knot on my head in the morning. Other than that, I'll be alright. Are you alright?"

Clay gave him a look. "Oh, give me some credit, Buddy, I've had more dangerous people come at me that this joker."

The wind blew in as Eliza tried to close the door. Clay waved at it and it swung closed, wind or no wind.

"You're telekinetic too?!" Robyn asked.

Clay looked at her and smiled. "I'm all kinds of things."

111212211.content:
"Oh, this is stupid!" Eliza stomped across the room to the door. When she pulled on the knob, the door fell off its hinges.

A ranger had a hand on his radio. "Is everything alright?"

"Oh, yeah, it's had a rough day. Can I help you?"

"I'm going down these roads to make sure everyone out here is alright. The weather's going to get nastier. Do you need anything?"

"No, we're fine, thanks. But what about the weather? How can it get much worse than this?"

"They're saying tornadoes, large hail, and flash flooding in some areas." The ranger froze. "Ma'am, is that a bear on your couch?!"

The color drained from the boys' faces. Eliza's eyes narrowed.

"That's my mother."

The ranger blushed. "Have a good night, ma'am. You be sure to call us at the station if you need anything."

"Hmm." She hoisted the door up in place (with some difficulty) and turned around.

Marcellus was gaping. "Wow."

"That was incredible." Clay said.

"That was pretty clever." Buddy sat up.

Robyn smiled at her.

There was another knock at the door. Eliza sighed.

"Apparently, he didn't get the hint the first time."

She pulled down the door. "Listen, sweetheart, we don't--"

She stopped. The light fell on a young blonde man. He was supremely beautiful. His eyes were the same sapphire blue as Clay's. He gave her a small smile and stepped into the room. He had four companions with him, a hooded young man with the same blue eyes and similar features, a nerdy looking guy with half-moon glasses, a beautiful (but normal-looking) young woman in a blue cloak, and a boy of about fifteen.

Clay hugged the young blonde guy. "Dad! It's been so long!"

Eliza spun around. Robyn frowned. Even Marcellus seemed a little confused.

"Wait, what?" Marcellus and Eliza said it together, made eye contact, and blushed, all the while feeling very silly.

The blonde guy turned to face them. "I don't have time to explain that right now. I am Azrael. I think we're all that's coming. At least for now."

"Who are you?" Robyn stepped right up to him.

"We're travellers. We've come a far greater distance than you can comprehend. That's not a insult to your inteligence, dear, it's simple truth. They journeyed all this way--" He gestured to his more normal-looking comrades. "--and can't tell you how, why, or how far. We came to protect you. We are, in a sense, Servants of God."

"Angels." Robyn said it like an accusation.

The girl laughed out loud. "I am no angel."

"Ditto!" Marcellus gave her a small salute. She smiled.

"Angels, wizards, wanderers, all true, and all irrelevant. Right now, we're here to protect you. We can't stay here much longer. The storm is just going to get worse."

"But, can't we just hold it back?" Clay asked. He seemed deeply troubled.

"You can, but we can only help a little. And when we start that, they'll know, and counteract us."

"We're not going anywhere with you people if you don't tell us what's going on!" Robyn was near tears. Eliza stepped over to her and held her. Clay could feel her mind's eye, only squinted but it had caught on to what was happening. She was scared.

"I know, dear. And we have enough time for that. Let's go to the kitchen."

Robyn drew a shaky breath. "Would you like some coffee?"

Azrael chuckled. "No thank you, dear." He put his hand on her cheek and stepped into the kitchen.
111212211.title: The Cavalry Arrives

1112122111.content:
Azrael sat across the old table from Robyn. Eliza sat beside her. Adonis and Clay flanked Azrael on either side, with Marcellus sitting next to Eliza, the boy sitting next to Clay on the narrower end, and the other two stood behind Clay and Azrael. The bear sat opposite the boy.

"As I said before, we've come a long way." Azrael spoke softly. "There is a group, very secretive and very powerful, that has targeted a handful of people in this world, including the two of you. They're exact intentions are not clear, but the overall effect they're having on this world is one of darkness and fear. Many of their agents come from other worlds. Likewise, we who fight them come from other worlds. We've come here, to this house, to protect the two of you and get you out of this cabin."

"We know your name," Eliza said. "And Marcellus, and Clay. But who are the others?"

"I'm Adonis." The hooded guy spoke up. "I'm Azrael's nephew."

Robyn frowned. They looked nearly the same age.

"I'm Ila." The beautiful girl pulled out a compact.

"I'm Joey," the boy added. "And this is Simon Zarathustra."

The nerdy guy smiled and waved.

"What a mouthful." Robyn said. Simon blushed and looked away.

Eliza leaned over. "I think you made him uncomfortable."

Robyn looked up at Simon. "Sorry."

Simon smiled a little and nodded.

Robyn met Azrael's gaze. "So what do we do now?"

"Well, as I said before, we need to get you out of this cabin. They've located you, and more will be coming soon. Or, as Adonis has pointed out to me, we could stay in the cabin and hold them off until we can send for help. Either way will be exhausting."

Robyn turned to Eliza. "What do you think?"

Eliza gaped at her. "You trust him?"

"Yes. I do." She said it very bluntly.

"You don't trust anybody."

"Well, I trust him."

"But what should we do?"

Robyn took a moment to think.

111212211121.content:
The sky boomed. Eliza and Joey screamed. Clay looked up. His eyes flashed briefly with a white light. The rain slacked off. The wind died down. The lightning and thunder all but disappeared, until it remained only on the fringes of the horizon.

The rain finally stopped completely. A hand reached out from the hole in the wall and grabbed Marcellus by the hair.

"HEEY!!" He grabbed his sword and swung. The fire scorched the monster's arm. More flew out of the house. In all, there were seven.

Ila drew a wand from her cloak. "Sea Salt!"

The monster nearest to her turned into salt and fell to the ground in a heap. The other monsters shrieked and flew around in a frenzy. Eliza and Robyn clung to Azrael. Simon pulled a small crystal ball out of his pocket. He waved his free hand over it, chanting in a strange language. Light rose up out of the crystal ball and caused two of them to evaporate. Joey opened a glass phial and slung the contents onto the nearest of them. One dissolved completely. Two others lost limbs.

"What's in that stuff?!" Marcellus asked.

One of the monsters moved to engage Adonis. Adonis raised his hand. Light beamed from his fingertips. The monster dried up and floated away like ash.

The other two flew up into the air and swooped back down. They opened their mouths wide. They were coming down on the girls.

Azrael's entire body flashed with white light. The monsters combusted, and blew away like dust.

"We should be fine for a while." Azrael said. "Let's go down the south path down the hill. It'll be easier and safer."

I took this opportunity to eat some of the food stored in my backpack. I reached into the bag and pulled out a sandwich and a can of mountain dew. Ten minutes later, I heard footsteps in the distance. I stopped eating and waited as the footsteps grew closer and closer. Soon, a figure appeared. "well, what are you doing in this downpour? Not exactly safe on this hill."

11121221112111.content:
"Well.."

"I can answer that." Came a mysterious voice.
From out of nowhere stood a man wearing black dress pants and a black dress shirt and waist coat with a silver tie. He appeared to be in his mid-twenties though it was hard to tell from the down-turned trilby which concealed half his face. He held his hands behinds his back and seemed to be completely unaffected by the storm.

"Now I can answer how the storm started but I sadly cannot answer why the storm persists."

"Who the hell are you?" Azrael interjected.

"Oh how rude of me, my name is Maxwell Black, at your service." The stranger says with a bow, revealing that his hands are pitch black with a strange glossy look about them.

Great bolts of lightning shot down from above. The boulders flashed briefly before they vanished. Dust fell upon the camp. In the distance, a horrific ripping sound rose into the sky. In the distance, a hill was ascending while a great maw opened in the earth at the base of a new limestone cliff. Shadows swarmed out of the abyss and descended upon them. Many could not survive their impact with the Elven shields, but those that could began to claw it open, and this was enormously effective. Eliza and Robyn backed into a narrow space between two tents. A hand grabbed them from behind.

"GET AWAY FROM MEE!!!" Robyn shrieked. She turned swinging. Clay caught her hand.

"WHOA! That would've broken my nose!"

"What do we do?" Eliza asked.

"Well, we retreat. Hastily."

"How?" Robyn looked around. The shadows were locked in fierce combat with the elf armies. Adonis and Azrael were handling themselves well, and saving many lives in the process.

Simon ran to them. "Let's grab Joey and slip out."

"Where's Ila and Marcellus?"

"Ila's helping Marcellus get to a safe place and she plans to join the fighting."

"Where's Joey?"

Simon blinked. "Well, actually, he's right there." He pointed behind Clay. Joey strolled up and grinned briefly.

"Hey."

Clay nodded. "Alright. Simon, you and Joey sneak out the back. I'll get the girls out. Meet us on the trail."

They dashed away. Clay wrapped his arms around each girl's waist.

"Hold on."

He flashed with pure white light, and he had six white wings. They pointed up and slammed down. All three of them vaulted high into the air, above even the shadows. Eliza squealed and buried her head in his chest. Robyn watched, wide-eyed, but otherwise paid attention to her surroundings.

The battle below was ferocious. The shadows were inflicting heavy damage, but they were generally vanquished by magic and the light emanating from Azrael and Adonis. A few Elves discovered that prayer worked against the monsters, and the idea was spreading through the camp.

"Coming down. Everybody hold on."

He brought them down quite gently on the path. Marcellus was leaning against a tree trunk. Relix was with him.

Marcellus looked unhappy and disappointed. "How is it out there?"

Clay sighed. "Brutal."

Marcellus shook his head. "I want to be out there!"

"I know. But we have to keep moving. We have to keep them safe."

"Keep them safe?" Relix stepped forward. "What about Marcellus? How are we to keep him safe?"

Clay frowned. "Marcellus is a tough guy. I have complete faith that he can take care of himself."

"Of course you would say that, Angel." He said it like a swear word. "'He only helps those who help themselves.' Isn't that what your kind is always spouting?"

"Wait a second, my kind? What is THAT supposed to mean?"

"I'm just saying, what's illness and injury to someone who can't die?"

"Wait, stop." His voice cracked a bit on the last word. Only Robyn was astute enough to notice.

"You'll just keep on trucking. This life is unimportant, right? It doesn't mean much, right? So if he keeps on, keeps losing blood, then it won't really matter when he drops dead at your feet!"

Relix charged at him. His entire body was starting to bristle and pulse. The girls ran in opposite directions away from them. Clay raised a hand.

"Vaiyar Elohim et ha'ovr ki tov; vaiyav del Elohim, bein ha'ovr uvein ha'khoshekh!"

Robyn didn't understand the language, but the meaning was imprinted on her heart: "And saw God the light that was good; seperated, God, the light from the darkness." In that moment, Robyn and Eliza observed the world in distressing extremes: pure white light, represented by Clay, wings engaged, halo blazing, and ink black shadow, represented by Relix, and everything else was colored one of the two hues. Relix screamed and flew back twenty feet, and the moment was over.

Clay stepped over to Relix on the ground. There were tears in his eyes.

"I am Ben Malak Ha-Mavet. You will not underestimate my respect for life, do you got me?"

Relix clenched his jaw and nodded.

"Now," Clay continued. "When I said we need to keep moving, I meant for the safety of everyone involved. That includes Marcellus. In a few minutes, the fray will make its way to this spot. We have to leave before it does. We have to find somewhere safe to hole up for the night. Preferably somewhere weatherproof. My brain needs to rest awhile from keeping this weather in check."

"You're the one stopping it?" Relix seemed shocked.

"Young does not mean powerless, Relix. You know that better than anyone."

Relix nodded. "If we're going to go, we need to make sure Marcellus won't come to any further damage while we're moving."

"I'll be fine." Marcellus sounded much better than he had the last time they spoke.

Relix stood up. "No, you aren't, you say that every time you take a hit! Remember when you tried to fight after your ankle was broken?"

"Oh, come on, that was ONE TIME!"

Relix helped Marcellus up. Clay stepped over and pulled Marcellus' arm over his shoulders so he could help him walk.

"I've got him. You just help me keep an eye on the girls."

Relix rolled his eyes. "Fine."

Joey and Simon ran up from the battlefield.

"What took you so long?" Clay asked.

"We were nearly killed." Simon's breath was coming very quickly. "A gaggle of them swarmed us. We would've been gone if Joey hadn't the good sense to pray."

"Well, it's good that you made it." Marcellus said. "We're about to leave now."

"What about the others?" Joey asked.

"They'll meet us." Clay said. "Let's just go while we can."

A tree fell down somewhere close behind them.

"Aw, what now?!" Relix groaned.

Eliza opened her eyes. The clock read 4:30 A.M. She turned onto her back and sighed. The streetlights outside the curtains made fantastic shadows on the ceiling.

"Can't sleep?" Robyn asked. She was laying beside her. In the other bed, Ila slept snuggled next to the bear. The boys were in another room. They'd come across the Armstice Motel as they came down the mountain from the battlefield. Clay was preparing to hypnotize the young man at the desk, but Robyn pulled out a credit card and marched inside. When she came out, she was jingling the keys in one hand with a grin on her face, saying, "See? I can contribute!" The Armstice was relatively close to town but still secluded, it was clean, and above all, it was nearly empty. Once inside, Clay sat on the edge of the bed, and as the rain started to come down again, the tension visibly released in his face. Ila conjured a delicious meal. As the night dragged on, the Armstice granted them the quiet they'd been searching for. Some time around one-forty, they heard a terrific boom a ways up the mountain to the north, and all was silent until the police drove past to investigate the noise.

Eliza closed her eyes and took a deep breath. "I was. I'm not now. Not sure why."

"Did you sleep badly?"

"No, not at all. Suddenly I'm wide awake, though."

"I am too. I'm blaming you."

"Fair enough."

They stared up at the ceiling.

"You wanna go outside?" Eliza asked.

"Sure." Robyn climbed out of the bed and wrapped the complimentary robe around the both of them. They hugged each other and stepped outside. The weather wasn't nearly as cold as they would've thought. The rain had stopped, and they could see a few bright stars in the sky.

"Morning, sunny." Marcelus was sitting just outside the door to the boys' room without a shirt, leaning against Clay while Simon applied a topical solution to his wound.

"I thought Azrael healed that for you." Robyn said.

"He couldn't heal it all the way because Mar wanted a scar," Clay said.

The girls sat down in between their door and Clay.

"So," Eliza said. "Someone promised to tell me what was going on."

Clay nodded. "Well, it's the shadows. They're looking to come after you."

"Why?" Robyn asked.

Clay shrugged. "Well, we're not sure, exactly. It seems to be related to an innate power within the two of you. It attracts them."

"But what are they?" Eliza asked.

Mar groaned in discomfort and leaned more of his weight into Clay. Clay resituated a bit to Mar would be more comfortable and he answered.

"The shadows are beings of dark energy. They've always been present in the cosmos. No one's sure exactly where they come from, but they're believed to have evolved from the chaos at the beginning of creation. They're essentially dark destruction manifest in a semi-corporeal form. They don't think in the sense that you or I think, but they calculate like a computer. There's no emotion at all, just cold facts and logistics and numbers. It's like telepathic hell."

The girls shivered and huddled a bit tighter.

"So they're coming back for us?" Robyn asked. Her voice was starting to quiver. "Will they track us here?"

"No, we're safe." Clay put his other arm around them. "The sun will be up soon, and we can head out when Adonis gets here in a few hours with the van."

"But where will we go?" Eliza asked. "I mean, I'll go, but where? And to what?"

111212211121211212222122222111221.content:
The van rolled along the Interstate through wide green fields. The sky above was a perfect blue, and the few clouds were white and immaculate.

Adonis took another bite from his third burger. When stopping at the drive-thru, he ordered twenty-five double cheeseburgers that everyone seemed to agree with (except for Relix, who rather politely asked to be let out of the van so he could go to the Taco Bell next door; he came back with a back of tacos and a single response--"I just wanted some tacos"--for Robyn when she gave him a questioning look).

Everyone dug into the food happily, and even a hundred and fifty miles down the road, there were still seven burgers and two tacos. The conversation was light and good-natured. As Adonis bit into the burger, Ila pulled a handful of heavy books from the air.

Eliza shook her head. "How DO you do that?"

Ila chuckled. "All in due time."

Robyn fingered the book nearest to her with a growing light in her eyes. "Can I see this one?"

Ila inspected the binding and handed it over before waving a hand over a book with a purple cover and skimming the pages with magic.

Robyn moved the book into her lap. On her other side, Clay glanced over.

"You've got it backwards."

Robyn looked up at him with a frown on her face. "Hmm?"

Clay picked it up and flipped it over so that the binding was on the right side. The golden script on the cover was a sort of pictographic alphabet that reminded her vaguely of the ancient Phoenician script she saw in college.

"What is this language?" she asked.

"It's written in the language of the Fae." Clay said.

"What's this say?" Robyn pointed at the cover.

"Roughly, it means 'A List of the Sons of Heaven'."

Robyn opened the cover and flipped a few pages into it. She found pictures of unearthly beautiful youths in varied colors. "Can you read this?"

"I can. I can also recognize those people. See this one?" He pointed to a dark-skinned beauty of a man in a red cloak with a trumpet. "That's Israfel. You know when people say 'so-and-so has the voice of an angel?' THAT'S the angel. He's Malak Ha-Zimarot, the Angel of Music."

She turned another page. This angel had white hair and golden eyes, in a pale yellow cloak.

"That's Uriel. He's the Angel of Light. Odd guy, that one. That stint guarding Eden did a number on him."

She turned a few more pages ahead. She wasn't sure what she was seeing exactly. The figure on the page didn't seem to have a shape she could focus her eyes on, but he had one, most definately.

"And this?" she asked softly.

Clay shivered. "That's Metatron. Malak Ha-Shem. The Angel of The Name."

"Hallelujah, Abba Shaddai." Adonis blurted it quite by accident.

"Have you met him?"

"Yes. Briefly. He's got his gig, I've got mine. Rarely do the two ever meet."

"What gig would that be?" Eliza asked.

Clay grinned a little. "Keep flipping. I'm in there."

Robyn turned another page. This one was red-headed, with bright green eyes and a beautiful bow.

"Malak Ahava. Cupid." Clay said.

Robyn turned another page. It was Azrael, but there were two of him on the page. One, dressed in a hooded black cloak, bent his head in serene prayer, while the other, a figure dressed in fine black and red clothing, glared out at the world from the page with a pair of large black horns protruding from his forehead.

"Malakim Ha-Mavet," Clay said. "The Angels of Death. Azrael and his brother."

"His brother?" Robyn looked up at him.

"When the angels appeared on the earth, they were like embryos," Clay said. "They swam around in the sea while they developed. One of them split in half. In humans, we call it monozygotic twins."

"What's wrong with his brother?" Robyn asked. She'd lost the color in her face.

"He's been corrupted by his own power," Clay said solemnly. "He sought to subject the mortals to angelic will, since they are weaker. The Lord was displeased with this, since his love for the mortals is greater even than his love for us."

"You don't sound very upset about that." Relix eyed Clay from above one of the last two tacos.

Clay shrugged. "What is there to be upset about? It's the way it is. He couldn't accept that. So he sought to make them submit or perish."

"So as Death, that was fairly easy, I guess?" Eliza scooted closer to Clay to get a look at this book.

"Not really," Clay said. "On the one hand, yes, because he has tremendous power. On the other hand, no, because that sort of death isn't his strong suit."

"There's only one kind of death." Relix growled. "The mortal kind."

Adonis snickered and shook his head.

"You'd think that." Clay said. "The two of them together represent the two kinds of Death. There's the physical, like Relix said. That's Azrael. But there's also spiritual death, the death that comes to the soul when it is seperated eternally from God. That one's Lucifer."

Robyn flipped further ahead. She came to a section near the end of the book marked with a word in green, a word Clay read as "bariim," and translated as "sons."

"Sons of who?" Eliza asked.

"The angels." Clay said.

Relix frowned. "Like adoption?"

"No, not like adoption," Clay said. "Biologically. It's something they've been doing for millenia. Every century, a selected angel will pick a human woman on the earth to bear his child. When he's old enough, he goes to the Land of Nod on the planet Lucidum so that he may live among people who practice magic and face many great dangers. It's a rite of passage for us, a chance to face the kind of enemies that don't exist in this world."

Robyn flipped through it. She found a page with two pictures on it: one of Adonis holding a candle for an old lady and one of Clay consoling a crying boy while he led him away from his lifeless body.

"What does this say?" She pointed to the text.

"Sons of the Deaths," Clay said. "That's my gig, right there."

He pointed to the picture of himself with the boy. Robyn and Eliza studied it and felt their hearts drop when they realized its meaning.

"Is it hard?" Eliza whispered.

Clay shook his head. "By the time I get there, the worst has already happened. I give them release and lead them to light. It's mainly about helping them accept what's happened to them and getting them safely to judgement."

"He judges children?" Relix grew stiff and apprehensive.

"All must face the Throne," Clay said. "Very few children receive punishment. Almost all proceed directly to the appropriate sphere in Heaven."

The van was silent in thought. Robyn closed the book and handed it back to Ila. No one spoke. Eliza wiped the tears from her eyes with the heel of her hand. Relix looked out the window of the back door in grave contemplation. In the front seat, Adonis leaned up and turned the dial on the radio volume. "Life is a Highway" barrelled out of the speakers, and before long, the entire van was laughing and singing while Relix cringed and Marcellus snapped out of his doze with a loud "WHA??" that made everyone present laugh even harder.

11121221112121121222212222211122112.content:
The bar was done up in a rustic look, with oak paneling and wooden floors, a fireplace, Guiness and Jack Daniels signs up around the room. The gang headed for a couple of booths in a corner of the bar that was away from the bulk of the patronage, gathered around the bar and pool tables, closer to the bathrooms. Relix approached the bar, fumbling for his wallet and withdrawing the credit card and false ID that he'd obtained from a skinny meth fiend who sold these items from a spot in an alley in a seedier part of Dallas, Texas, not far from where he'd found himself when he entered this world from his own. The barkeep, a plump redheaded man of clear Scots-Irish descent, handed him keys to a three-room suite, the largest accomodations then available, in the motel behind the bar.

You're being watched.

Relix glanced around. No one seemed to notice anything.

Don't look.

His spine stiffened. He frowned but quickly fixed his face so that the barkeep wouldn't notice.

You shall meet with me soon enough. Just order drinks, go back to your group, and relax. Head for the back door and expect trouble when you make it outside. That you have a scuffle in your future is inevitable--don't dare try to avoid it. The best of all possible outcomes is beyond the back door, and nowhere else.

"Will that be all, Mr. Johnson?"

Relix glanced up at the barkeep. "Round of shots. Tequila. Eight."

The barkeep nodded. "You can rejoin your party. Maryann will bring you your drinks directly."

Relix thanked the man stiffly, reclaimed his cards, and stepped back over to the group. As he sat down, the group was trying to have a conversation over the partition seperating the booths.

Okay, what is it?

The voice was Clay's this time, in Relix's mind, not spoken aloud. He glanced up, met Clay's gaze and felt aggitation rise in his chest.

How do people keep doing that? Relix asked.

I'm an angel. We have our ways. But what do you mean?

Relix played through the incident in his head, hoping the telepathic SOB would pick up on it. The small, inperceptible nod Clay gave him told him he did.

Play it cool. We can handle anything that comes our way.

A pretty girl with black hair in a white shirt that was a bit too small stepped over with eight tall shot glasses full of clear yellowish liquid on a tray, and a plate with sixteen sliced limes. She set the tray on Relix's table, smiled, and walked away. Clay took one of the glasses and eyed Relix.

"Tequila? Really? Is this because I'm Mexican or something?"

Play along. Clay told Relix.

Relix smirked. "Oh, if only everything I did revolved around you."

The group grabbed their shots and lime slices. Robyn handed Eliza hers, since Eliza was in the middle of the booth, and Eliza cooed, "Oooo! How did you know the way to my heart, Relix?"

"Okay, I'll just say it, what the Hell is this?" Ila held her glass in front of her with a suspicious half smile.

"It's tequila," Eliza said. "It makes the world better."

Simon leaned over. "Alcoholic drink. Distilled from a flowering succulent desert plant found in Clay's native country."

"Here, I'll show you how to do this shizz right." Eliza wet her index finger and dabbed it in the salt shaker. "Do like so. Guys in the back, are you paying attention?"

They all followed suit. Eliza sucked the salt off her finger. When the rest did the same, she said, "Now, this next part is tricky. You have to do it fast." She brought the shot to her mouth and downed it, and bit into her lime slice. The others tried to do the same, but half of them gagged on the tequila before they managed to get their lime. Ila's lime fell from her mouth, and with accusing eyes and ragged voice she turned to Eliza and croaked, "You lying bitch."

Marcellus and Adonis found this hilarious, and let loose a bray of laughter.

"Say, did you get us a room?" Robyn was addressing Relix. "Because I can do it, it's not a problem."

Relix pulled the keys out of his pocket. Robyn grinned.

"Good, can we head that way now? I'm tired."

Relix felt anxiety flare up inside. Clay patted his knee under the table, so no one would see. Relix met his eyes and they both agreed it was time. They rose and the group followed them to the back of the bar and out the back door wordlessly but wearing their confusion on their faces.

When the door shut, five creatures floated down out of the sky. They weren't shadows, but they were far uglier. They were winged creatures, averaging four to a beast, with seven beady eyes set in their bald heads, in between their twisted black horns. Their hands were claws, their feet cloven hooves, and they emanated an air of malice and blank hatred, and black shadow rimmed them like halos, horrific parodies of the unspeakable beauty of Clay or Adonis. Robyn, the third most psychic person in attendance, felt their evil and their madness and her bladder let go.

"Demons." Adonis muttered.

Clay looked at Relix. "Ready?"

Relix drew his sword slowly and nodded. "Yeah."

"Ila?"

"You got it, Kiddo."

"You're not keeping me out of this one." Marcellus stepped past the girls and pulled out his sword. The creatures screeched and moved forward with astonishing speed. Clay swiped at one of them and it exploded in a plume of flame and ash. Marcellus stepped out of another's path (danced, it looked like) and sliced its wings off as it passed. Ila took it out with a blue light from her hands that turned it to mud. Adonis waved another one out of existence, and Relix managed to decapitate the last one. This didn't kill it, however, and it clawed at him with more fury than before. Relix felt blinding terror for the first time in quite awhile, but a female voice, THE voice, called out in a strange language and a passing falling star changed course and vaporized it upon impact.

Robyn tried to cover her accident with her hands. Hot furious tears spilled down her face. No one had noticed yet in all the action, save for Simon and, before anyone could see, he threw a spell that, rather than replacing the jeans (that would've been beyond his abilities), he switched them with his own, about the same size, and tried not to grimace at the warm wetness.

Clay turned around and grimaced. "Oo. Simon. Are you alright?"

Simon turned a new shade of scarlet. "Um..."

"It's alright, I'll fix it." Ila waved her wand and the soiled pants were replaced with nice blue silk ones, not what he had in mind but better than before.

"Thanks." Simon muttered.

A gorgeous blonde bombshell in a tight black dress stepped forward from the other side of the building. She wore a wide-brimmed black hat that rose in a lopsided cone.

"Golden Hell." Ila gasped.

Eliza frowned. "What's wrong? Who is she?"

Clay stiffened. In another world, the blonde had kidnapped the boy king and led a revolt that cost thousands, even going to far as to attempt (if only once) to have her forces kill Clay himself.

"Anama," Ila said. "My sister."

1112122112112111222111111111111112111212.content:
Kronous withdrew the katana, his mind racing. Everyone had gone off already, but Anderson and Darion stood besdie him.
"You've gotten more organized in your attacks," Darion muttered," I'm impressed."
"When destiny calls," Kronous said, pointing the tip of his sword at the battle," you must always be organized, whether your going to die or not."
"I have an idea for you," Anderson said to Kronous," and its worth hearing."
"I'll listen to whatever you have to say," Kronous said, turning to Anderson,"I'm all ears."

-------

Sev couldn't believe this many people would serve under an ancient deity. Most of them had most likely thought of getting a special reward for serving, but it was all lies, Sev thought. He swung his mace over his head, crushing one attackers' skull in while crushing three others' ribs. Sev had always admired Kronous, espically since the hardships he had been put through. But that alone will not really help in this battle. Sev had found werewolves attacking with templars quite odd, but this was nesscary, and Faopaw lead a relatively peaceful pack, who only raids against their nocturnal, blood sucking counterparts. But, something seemed....off in Ctlhulhu's army. It seemed as if the enemy had no fighting spirit, but fought against their will. Sev suddenly grinned, knowing that he could possibly influence them to join their side.
"We've got them on the run!" Faopaw howled, cutting through countless merceniares in a matter of seconds," the fury of the pack knows no bounds!"
"Don't celebrate just yet!" Sev yelled, smashing another head in,"we've got a long ways to go!"

-------

Kronous nodded. Faopaw and Sev had done well keeping the attention of the enemies left flank, allowing him to act for his second attack, a ambush that would annhilate their entire right flank.
"You still able to summon dracolichs, Darion?" Kronous mused as he turned to Darion," if you are, that will greatly help destroy the enemies spirit."
"Of course! Just cuz I'm not summoning skeletons or throwing my axe at people doesn't mean I can summon multiple dracolichs!" Darion said, delibrately making the phrase confusing.
"Good. Send at the very least a dozen dracolichs to aid Kaneda and her small group of ambushers. It shall prove intresting."

-------

Kaneda waited, sitting in a tree. She toyed with the idea of just immediaetly going out and attacking, but Kronous gave her specific instructions not to. She had to wiat for an unusual cue, but she waited.
" I grow bored of this," she heard a ninja groan," why can't we attack now?"
"Paitence," Kaneda said with a soothing voice,"we wait for a cue, then we can attack."
Kaneda heard the very unfamiliar flapping of....bones? No, that couldn't be right. She climbed to the top of the tree, and saw dracolichs coming her way. Kaneda squinted and saw Darion riding a top the one leading the others. Kaneda jumped down and signaled the others. The time was now. As the small group ran, they heard a roar from one of the dracolichs, signaling it's attack. Portions of enemies disappeared without a trace, just to be found in re¥ote places as stiffening corpes. And by the time Darion and Kaneda met up, the right flank was either in disarray or in a madden attempt to flee.
"Well, I gotta report back to Kronous," Darion said, climbing ounto the massive dracolich," he told me to tell you to meet up with Sev and the werewolf guy after you've finished up here."
"Tell him I will do whatever it takes to do so." Kaneda said with a smile.

-------

"The ENTIRE right flank?" Kronous asked, not believeing Darion.
"Aye. We did as you asked." Darion said with a grin," You gave us orders to."
"Wow. I did not know that attack would be very successful." Kronous said, pacing this threw him into his final phase: a strangling of the enemies army, and where he joined the fight himself.
"Leon and Sen-gie are doing well holding the front line with the templers and your furry warriors." Darion said, regarding the areas where Kronous had sen everybody," I am very impressed with how your doing this."
"I'm impressed with myself in fact," Kronous said proudly,"This actually may be a very well-coordianted attack."
"Don't get to ahead of yourself," Darion muttered," we still have Anderson out there posing as you."
"Bah! The old man and I agreed to do this, and we shall do it, and it falls into place with my final attack!" Kronous said, lifting his sword up," I'll not be defeated by some false god who thinks himself high and mighty! For honour!"
"For honour!" Darion yelled.

-------

The minute Kronous stepped out on to the battle field, he felt the bloodlust in his head begin to urge him on. Kronous would live and die by his blade, he wasn't afraid of death, although he certainly knew others were afraid for him. He rushed through his enemies not giving any time for either him or his foes for any rest. And by the time he did stop, he noticed the front line had surged forward, cutting down more and more enemies with renewed vigor.
"Your a good fighter!" Leon yelled over to Kronous,"... Wow, I'm surprised I admited that!"
"Your pretty good yourself!" Kronous yelled back.
Kronous immediately caught sight of Sev and Faopaw on the left, while he caught Kaneda and her group on the right. His plan was actually working, which surprised the hell out of him. He suddenly broke from the lines and ran in the direction of where Ctlhulhu was commanding his now shattered army. Kronous caught up with Anderson, who was running in the same direction as he was.
"I take it you inspired fear into our enemies, old man?" Kronous asked with a grin.
"Quite right, pup." Anderson shot back,"Now we stick to our agreement."
"I can't believe that we agreed to this." Kronous muttered," and if you do die, who will I have as a rival?!"
"You can fight Darion. He's young and can wrestle a bear to the ground."
"Heh heh heh. I remember that." Kronous snickered.
They got to the main camp just in time to see Ctlhulhu outraged by the defeat of his army with such simple tactics.
"I will devour this world!" Ctlhulhu howled oddly," and I'll begin with you two!"

-----------

Kronous had panicked moment for a second. But he found him standing off with Anderson against Ctlhulhu, who contiuned to howl with anger. By the time he actually made an attack, both Anderson and Kronous were caught off guard and were thrown in diffrent directions. Damn, Kronous thought as he got up, how can something that big move that fast?! Kronous charged the creature for some reason, and in his mind he knew it was foolish, but it gave Anderson enough time to attack it's vunerable backside. Howling with pain, Ctlhulhu threw Anderson off of it and lumbered forward to crush the priest, but that gave Kronous enough time to deal damage of his own. Making multiple slashes on Ctlhulhu's back Kronous kept it going unitl he felt that he had angered the false god into attacking him now.
"You will fall, false god!" Kronous roared," and if I fall, I'll take you with me!"
Kronous braced himself for the rampage that Ctlhulhu was about to hit him with, but Anderson intervened and took the blunt blow. Staggering, the priest threw bayonets into Ctlhulhu's eyes.
"Good....l-luck, lad," Anderson sputtered, falling to his knees," you'll n-need it...ugh.."
Kronous charged with renew fury, slicing into diffrent parts of the false god as quickly as possible. He saw Ctlhulhu just freeze up.
"What!? I am immortal! I..will..be back...for your..." Ctlhulhu said, gutted like a fish.
A green glow and Ctlhulhu was gone, but Kronous had no clue of that since he hit the ground hard out of exhaustion.
