1112122112112111222111111111111112111212.content:
Hikari, nikki, and anyone who was left behind were charged with dealing with the straglers.
Any enemy who slipped through..or who the main fighters missed were killed by them.

Nikki knelt beside kronos and helped him to his feet.
After rejuvenating him with the blood from a fresh enemy corpse, the team gathered.
" I can't believe it's over..."
Hikari smiled as she leaned in to Kronous.

" It seems unreal..."
Laughter rang in the air...
It couldn't be....

Ctlhulhu rose from the ground as a giant rotting corpse and swaggered back and forth.
"Fools!
None can kill me!"
The team looked at each other....and nodded.

Each ran at the monster..attacking it with all they had left.
Darion with his axe...
Kaneda with her ninja skills...
Hikari cast powerful scrolls at it...
Leon sliced and shot the creature....

Ctlhulhu fell to the ground.
" You shall never be rid of me....
You hear me?"
His words were cut short.
Sen-gie had skewered the beast from behind with his handmade spear.

The team looked on in astonishment.
"Where did you come from?"
He smirked.
"When Hikari was resurrected, you brought me back as well.
You just didn't notice."

The team laughed.
Kronous looked at leon.
"What will you do now?"
He looked at Nikki.

" I think we deserve a little time to ourselves...
Maybe somewhere in the mountains..."
Nikki cuddled close...a smile crossing her face.

"And what of you?"
Kronous drew Hikari close.
"We shall try and make it work....
Give Anderson a proper burial...Try to patch things up at the elven city...and live our lives peacefully...
If we can..."
Kaneda stood beside them.

" I will also be there...for both you and the child.
I've never babysat..."
Kronous smiled..then turned to Sen-gie and Darion.

" I suppose you will continue to fight?"
Darion nodded.
"You know me.....action..all day...every day.
If I left it behind...I'd get bored..."
Sen-gie stood beside him.

" I might as well tag along...
The youth of today can never stay out of trouble."
Sev and Faopaw stood behind them as well.
Each group cried tears of sadness and joy as they said their goodbyes.

As the groups went their separate ways, they glanced back..only once...
The same question crossed all their minds...
Would they ever meet again?

Kronous raised his sword to the sky.
"Till the next battle comes....
May we stand side by side again!"

Cheers rang from all groups.
Hikari hugged herself close to her lover.
This life they were about to embrace.....
This world they could now explore....

He would always be by her side....
And her friends would always be in her heart....

THE END

He reached behind his back and grasped the cold metal, pulling the gun out of his waist band. He sighed in annoyance and shot his weapon in the direction of the girl. Jasper slipped his gun into the back of his waist band and crossed his arms, waiting for Robyn to slow to a stop in front of him.
"What's an innocent little girl like you doing, running around being chased by Them?" Jasper asked mockingly.
"Oh please," Robyn replied exasperatedly, "I'm not innocent."
Jasper chuckled while turning around and walking down the road, "I've done my research sweet heart, and believe me, I've seen way worse than stealing candy bars from your local convenience store."
Robyn scowled and followed after him, "I don't need this right now. One of my friends just died, stop trying to make my day worse."
Jasper sighed and glanced at her sardonically, "I'm sorry for your loss but I'm not here to make your day worse. If I was then I would've let that repulsing beast have you for lunch."
"Fine, you saved the day, now who are you?!" Robyn asked.
"Name's Jasper, today I'll be your Knight In Shining Armor, how may I be of assistance?" He replied dryly.
"There's no need for your snooty comments, I think we can survive with out the attitude."
"I personally think our situation needs a little humor," Jasper said turning into the undergrowth off the side of the road.
"I don't see how you can find humor in this," Robyn replied angrily then added, "Where exactly are we going?"
"Well seeing as I'm Prince Charming, we're going to my majestic castle just over the hills of nonexistence."
"Seriously, cut the crap, where are we going?" Robyn persisted.
Jasper looked at her, "You're the mind reader, you tell me."
"Oh so now you want me to sort through your deep dark secrets and learn the positions of all your precious keepsakes?" Robyn threatened.
"Hm, good point, it's not like you'll be able to find my precious keep sakes anyways seeing as we have about a 36.4% chance of making it out of here alive," Jasper paused and jumped onto a rather tall boulder to get a better view. "We're going to go east, towards the mountains, the creature's camp is near the river, to the west. If we move fast we can get away before tomorrow."
"How do I know I can trust you?" Robyn asked.
Jasper sent her an annoyed look, jumped off the boulder and continued walking. Robyn groaned and raced after him. They walked for a few miles before reaching a complete drop off cliff. Jasper looked up and down the overhang searching for a way over.
"There's no way across, we'll have to go down," Jasper explained leaping onto a rock ten feet below them. Robyn looked down hesitantly. "Come on princess," Jasper urged, "We're only a glass slipper and pumpkin carriage away from being safe." Robyn cursed under her breath before reluctantly jumping down next to Jasper. As soon as she landed a crack of a rock splitting sounded. The ground beneath them began to tremble. Jasper looked around mournfully before reaching in his pocket and pulling out a zip lining device the size of a small cookie. "I might be able to get the hook onto the cliff over there," Jasper shouted to Robyn pointing towards a large platform about fifty meters away. "It's either that or we fall."

Gyan had snuck out of his bedroom window to find a place where he could play his violin in peace. His parents never liked it when he played it in the house. They always complained about the noise. Presently, he sat inside a small cave. Certainly, it was a bit chilly, but he was sheltered from the pouring rain and, as long as he had his fiddle, he was perfectly happy.

It was during a brief pause in his playing that he heard the voices. Two women were arguing.

"We can't leave here," said one, who sounded like she was crying, or had been very recently.

"Like hell we can't," the other spat. "I was supposed to be alone at that cabin. You showing up was annoying enough. Then this one just wanders in like she owns the place and passes out. My cabin is not the freakin' Holiday Inn."

"But it's freezing out---"

"She won't notice, she's unconscious."

The voices trailed off. As soon as Gyan thought it was safe, he ventured out to see what had happened. Lying on the ground, soaked and still as death, was a young female. In the distance was a cabin, presumably where the voices had gone to. How could they just dump her like this, he asked himself. I must do something.

Gyan placed his fiddle down gently and went over to the girl. He knelt beside her, unsure of what to do. Suddenly, she sputtered and sat up. Gyan jumped back in surprise.

"Please, help me," she choked out.

Gyan was shaken, but he couldn't refuse. He helped her up and over to the cave.

"Thank you," she said, still shivering, but clearly grateful. "My name's Melody."

"I'm Gyan," he said, smiling. It felt good to help someone.

"I'm very sick," said Melody. "I've got a fever."

Gyan again could not refuse to help. "I'll go see if I can find someone."

1131211.content:
Erian woke with a start, trying to remember where he was and how he had got there. Days and nights of panicked running and hiding seemed to melt together into a hazy blur, but he forced his tired mind to work. Automatically, he took note of his surroundings and his current condition. He was leaning against something hard, and he could feel that the ground was dry, though his clothes still clung to him damply. His memories came back slowly, reluctantly. He had been caught in the rain and had decided to take shelter in the cave for the night. It was pitch black, and the darkness was so complete that he could not even see his own hand in front of him. The only light came from the faint moonlight that entered from the cave entrance a good distance away. What had been his fire was now nothing more but another dark shadow in the darkness with no trace of heat or light remaining.

Erian felt the bulge of the package in his inner coat pocket, reassuring himself that it was there, then shivered as the keening wind carried in the biting cold from the winter storm outside. Not for the first time, he wondered whether these days of being hunted were ever going to end. He would give almost anything to be warm and dry, and not hungry. He couldn’t remember the last time he hadn’t been hungry. It felt as if his stomach was trying to eat a hole through to his spine, but it was still better than the alternative.

Erian took out a flint and knife from his bag and stooped over the dim shadows of what remained of his firewood, planning to relight the fire. But just as he had managed to coax the beginning of a weak fire, he heard the splashing of someone wading through water and the sound of voices coming closer. His breath caught. He dropped the flint and knife from his hands, taking out the gun hidden inside his coat as he jumped to his feet, quickly kicking dirt over the nascent fire. His eyes were fixed unblinkingly at the entrance of the cave. Fear twisted at his insides, and exhaustion seemed to weigh down on his shoulders, but he ignored it all with a grim determination as he crouched down, feeling his way along the wall as he backed up deeper into the cave as silently and quickly as he could. He stopped when he felt the rough wall give way suddenly into a sharp corner. After a moment of blind feeling at the wall, he realized that it was a nook in the wall at the end of the cave.

Hearing the voices come closer, Erian ducked inside without a second thought, undoing the safety of his gun with a muffled, decisive click. His eyes held a hard, cold light as he tensed, waiting. If they wanted to catch him, they were going to pay a steep price. He wasn't going to go down without a fight, and he had already killed his share of people. He would do anything he needed to survive. The hand holding the gun trembled just slightly, and he shivered as another cold draft entered the cave.

The sound of splashing and raised voices came closer. "This is it," a male voice said. "She's right in here."

"Finally! Ugh, I'm soaked through!" an obnoxiously high voice complained. "I never thought that the road couldn't reach here..."

More footsteps. "It's so dark. Hey, Andrea do you have the flashlight?" another female voice said.

"No, don't you have it, Alexis?"

"What are you talking about? It should be in your bag."

Erian could hear the clatter of something metallic being set down, and the rustling of cloth. "It's not here. Are you sure you don't have it...?"

There was a moment of silence and more rustling of cloth and clattering of metal. "Could it be," Alexis said, her tone somewhat abashed. "that we left it in the car? Uh...Gyan, do you have an extra flashlight on you?"

The man named Gyan sighed in resignation. "It's alright, you two wait here. I'll go in and bring her back out." The footsteps continued closer. Erian gripped the gun even tighter, and quieted his breathing as he waited, ready to kill if need be.

It seemed as if with each step closer his heart beat louder and faster, and when the man was only three paces away it felt as if his heart would beat right out of his chest. But Erian forced himself to keep his breathing quiet, ignoring the sweat that moistened his palms and the protests of his tired muscles. He didn't know who this man or those two women were. They did not sound like the type of people who were his pursuers, but he had been tricked plenty of times before. Trust was not something he was accustomed to having. Not anymore. He could only hope that they would turn back without noticing him.

Suddenly, a startled squeak came from behind him, and he spun around just as something--or rather, someone--screamed and lunged into his stomach, throwing him hard against the cave wall. His gun fired, the sound of the gunshot echoing through confined space, followed soon after by other yells and the sound of rapid footfalls coming in their direction.

Erian pushed his assailant off roughly, and the moment that she—he realized now that it had been a woman from how light she had been—fell onto the ground with a cry of pain, a man lunged into the small space yelling “Melody! Are you alright?” Blinding light filled the small cave. “Who are you?!” Erian yelled out, blinded from the sudden light. He raised his gun and tried to direct it in the direction the man had come in, but the gun was knocked out of his grip. Next was a hard punch to the stomach, and he crumpled to the ground, groaning.

“Andrea?! Did you get him?” Alexis gasped. “Oh my god! He had a gun!”

“Ouch...I can’t feel my fingers,” Andrea complained. “It’s a good thing I took self-defense! Is he unconscious now?”

“I don’t think so,” Gyan said slowly. “I think he’s probably just incapacitated for the moment. Melody, how are you feeling?”

“I’m fine,” the woman named Melody said weakly. “Just a bit scared. I woke up alone in the dark and saw someone nearby, but it was a stranger with a gun waiting by the entrance. Then I heard your voice and I… Who is he?”

“I don’t know. He looks familiar though…” there was a sharp intake of breath. “Alexis?”

“Yeah?”

“Doesn’t he look like that man we saw on the news a week ago? The wanted criminal?”

“What!” Alexis gasped. “He really does! It’s not a joke! What are we going to do—”

“Watch out!”

Gyan’s cry of warning came too late. In what seemed like only an instant, Erian had lunged himself off the floor and had grabbed the woman closest to him by the hair. His nails had extended until they were like wickedly curved talons, and the cold moonlight reflected coldly from the burnished claws. A trickle of dark blood ran down the woman's neck where he had drawn the tip of a nail against it, after which his captive widened her eyes and stopped struggling, still as stone. The scent of fresh blood was intoxicating, and it took every fiber of his self control to control his hunger. Meat. Fresh meat. Blood and muscle. Peel away the skin, crack the skull--No! He gritted his teeth and forced his thoughts away from the scent, but it was like telling a starving a man to ignore the aromatic feast in the same room.

"I didn't want to hurt any of you," Erian growled. "I was only here to take shelter from the rain. You're not involved. If you promise not to tell anyone--"

"And what is this?" another voice said from the entrance.

I stand out in the pouring rain, tapping my fingers against my soaking wet jeans. No one answers.

I knock again. Still, there is no reply. I turn around to go when the door opens just a crack, letting out a sliver of flickering firelight.

"What do you want?" Shadowed in the light is a woman.

"My name's Caden. My wife is in the car. It's broken down. She needs help."

"Get it somewhere else." The woman starts to close the door. I don't let her. "I'm sorry--" From her tone of voice I can tell she's anything but-- "but I'm very busy."

That I can believe. "It won't take a moment. Just loan me your keys. I really need to get her to the hospital. You don't understand!"

"Maybe," the woman muses acidly, taking a step away from the door," I don't want to." She pushes hard against my hand that is blocking the door. I don't budge.

The fire inside flares up, illuminating for a brief moment the woman at the door. On her hand there is a wet, scarlet stain.

"It looks like you need help, too." I say.

"It's none of your business, mister. Go away."

I can't wait any longer. Nice isn't working; it never does. I push the door open. "Do you know who I am?"

"Should I care?" She shoots back.

"There was a robbery recently. One man was dead and two more were injured. They won't ever walk again."

Slowly she makes the connection. "The Caden?"

I smile at her, though from the look on her face I take it that it wasn't a very nice one. I don't care. "Look, lady, the way I see it, I have two options: one, I can take your keys. Two, if I'm feeling especially mean--Like, say, now--I can kill you and take them from your corpse."

With a molten scowl, she tosses them away from me. "Here," she mutters, "take them."

Effortlessly, I take them from the air. I turn away. As an afterthought, I add, "Thanks."

The woman's face softens a bit. She closes the door. "I hope you crash and die." She tells me.

With a smile, I walk over to the car and start it up. It's no wonder she was hesitant about handing over the keys. The car is a new Camaro, with an amazing custom paint job.

After sloshing around in the mud for a while, I finally get out. I pick up Elyse, And race down the slick highway to the hospital.

Something in my headlights stops me.

I scaned the darkened forest in front of me. 'Where <i>was</i> I heading?' I wondered. The man in the car was waiting for my answer.

"I'm heading..." the man watches me, probably thinking I have no sweet clue where the hell I was actually going. Which was true. "Um... that way..." I point ahead of me to a little light far off down the road and in the woods. The man follows my gaze, his expression confused. "To the cabin down there."

"Alright," he said, leaning over to open the passanger seat. "Hop in."

The drive was very short. It was helpful of him to take me the rest of the way, though it wouldn't have been that far a walk. The heater of the car blasted and warmed up my shaking hands and frozen toes, and I almost didn't want to leave. But soon we had pulled down the long dirt path leading farther into the woods and to the lodge's doorstep.

Two cars were parked in the driveway and one on the lawn. Deep tire tracks were dug into the muddy ground in front of the house behind the vehicle, and by the looks of it, it didn't seem as if the drive had cared much about the survival of the owner's lawn. Plus the car was still running. I didn't know why, but I had a sudden feeling of dread -- a certainty that something was wrong.

The log cabin wasn't very small. but it wasn't large either. By the light spilling onto the leafy ground, I could tell someone was awake inside. I was a little nervous, because I've never been to this place before and was afraid I would be rejected if I asked to stay the night. I didn't know what these people were like, but I couldn't stay out in this storm and freeze. I needed shelter.

"Well, this is it," the man said. He looked a few years older than me, maybe 24, and had dark black hair and cold, hard eyes, as if something dark or troubling was on his mind. But then again his words seemed friendly enough throughout the ride.

"Thank's for driving me this far man," I said, reaching for the handel and pushing the door open. I swung my legs out and stood up, sheilding myself with my arm from the powerful gusts of wind.

"No problem. Glad I could be of some help." The man then glanced at the entrance to the house, and his eyes narrowed as a look of caution came over him. Wondering what was wrong, I followed his gaze and stared. The door to the cabin was wide open, swinging back and forth on its hinges by the wind. The sight of it sent chills down my spine. Something was definately wrong.

Eyes unwavering, the man got out of his car and came to my side as I inched forward towards the open door, cautious. We cast each other a glance, and I nodded. Something serious was up.

We were just reaching the door and about to peer in, our minds racing and senses on alert, when all of a sudden....

A loud, deafening scream came from inside. Our hearts jumped, then plummeted as we saw the beaten body of a woman crumbled to the floor.

As Chase began crossing the road, he heard the sound of a car. As it got louder, he realised it was getting closer. The black-haired man turned his head and saw two lights heading towards him.

As is common with many near-death experiences, Chase’s life flashed before his eyes. He saw his younger self playing with his two dogs, Tucker and Coco, his soldier dad returning home, his first date with his girlfriend, his party after he graduated from high school and today, when he won the lottery, winning enough money to finally take his girlfriend on a trip to Switzerland, where he now planned to propose to her..

But now he would never get that chance...

...Or would he?

Before car could hit Chase, the brakes screeched as the vehicle came to a stop. Thanking God that he was alive, Chase made his way to the driver-side door as the driver rolled the window down.

“Are you okay?” Chase asked the two men in the car.

“Yeah, we’re fine.” the driver answered. “Just a little shaken, but otherwise alright.”

“Good to hear.” Chase replied. “Sorry about that. I was thinking about stuff and forgot to look before crossing.”

“It’s okay.” the driver assured. “Just be careful in the future.”

“Will do. Thanks.”

And with that, the driver rolled up his window and the car began moving. After a while, it was gone. Sighing, Chase continued his walk. After crossing the street, successfully this time, he continued on his way before reaching his part of town.

From frozen apples to the theft of a police squad car, Mariah thought, slowly getting out. But then thought better of it. It can't be theft if the man behind the wheel is dead too, can it? One such as he can't be said to own anything anymore, not where his brains were ... Anymore than she could be said to have a thing.

But she had watched from the culvert, impervious to the rain and wind, and even fear, as the woman that the officer stopped by the side of the road did her deed, and followed in the car as the murderer fled up the rain-drenched hill, towards the mansion at the top.

Her beacon, hadn't she been Mariah's beacon? The north star to all this craziness? The single thing she'd woken up to see in the forest? Well? Wasn't she dead? And wasn't that woman her guiding light? The frozen apples, and then the guiding light? They had slipped easily past someone in the woods, then a couple by a broken down car, the man angrily gesticulating, even waving a gun, then even past another car with a bleeding woman inside and an infant in the back seat, weeping like an open wound, and then by another man, who seemed to see them, but who hadn't been able to catch up? Then to watch the light break and bleed and evil pour out, and directionless pour in.

Mariah got in. She continued to follow the woman. Who looked back, dumbfounded at first, until she saw the phantom behind the wheel with the long, uncombed hair, and not the poor, brainless cop. Then she picked up her pace, and darted off the road, back into the trees, towards a darkened cabin-like structure lurking back there in the gloom. But just when Mariah was turning off herself, ready to plunge into the forest, there she appeared again at the top of the hill, near the mansion.

And now here she stood, still directionless, with the beacon most likely inside, and death in the car, and mysteriousness down on the road below. As she stood indecisive, blinking in the rain, a man lurched past (he who had been in the forest?!) with a gun. Seeing her, he suddenly stopped and hid his weapon. He seemed to want to turn, then seemed to think better of it. His feet stuttered in the wet gravel.

I guess, thought Mariah, I really must look a fright. I mean, being buried for who knows how long. And again the image of the frozen apples surfaced in her head.

"Jesus!" the man said, taking a firm step back. And his gun was out again. But it only wagged in the wet air, impotent. He quickly turned and went staggering back on towards the mansion.

Now all this time, Mariah had become aware of some sort of crawling sensation at the back of her neck, as though there were worms. She turned, and through the trees glimpsed that darker darkness, the cabin, or whatever it was, at the bottom of the hill. She felt watched, and felt angered by being watched, angry at being caught out, her dress in rags, her hair in such a state, and her poor grave beneath the ground with its perfect soil pillow how many miles away? By these strangers, these criminal strangers.

And if this road in the middle of nowhere in the middle of a storm wasn't a perfect highway now, she didn't know what. Because here came to her death-dulled ears the sound of yet another blurting, blatting, struggling car engine. And headlights splashed over her front.

"Who the hell're you?" asked the man when he saw Crispin Moss leaning on the side of the car.
         "Who needs to know?" he asked, peeking at him over the top of his black Aviators. He flicked his cigarette butt to the ground and put his hands in the pockets of his suit jacket.
         The man looked at Crispin in disgust, and scoffed. "You're...kinda on my car, dude."
         "Hey," Crispin said, putting his hands up in defense. "I was sent here...to make sure you didn't go anywhere today."
         The guy gave him the evil eye. "Ohhhkayy? And who told you to do that?"
         "Top secret," he said. "But what I can tell you is that you're in a load of trouble."
         The guy's pulse rose; Crispin could hear it.
         He grinned, and casually twisted the crested ring on his finger. He shifted his weight from one leg to the other, and rested his foot on the front wheel of the tired old Volkswagen. He thought the car was a bit pathetic.
         Mr. Moss has always had a knack for getting whatever he wants, but this guy seemed to be putting up a bit of a fight, and, quite frankly, it was pissing him off.
         The guy spoke again. "What the hell are you talking about? I haven't done anything!"
         Crispin raised his left eyebrow. "You haven't, you say?"
         He pursed his lips, and Crispin pulled a file out of his briefcase. Damn briefcases, he thought, I feel so lame.
         "If you haven't done anything," he said, "then I suppose this diagram won't be familiar to you?" Crispin forced the paper in front of the man's face.
         The guy tensed when his eyes scanned the paper. There was a symbol. A strange symbol, at that. It was elliptical, and in the center, there was a cross. It had odd writing on the edges, in a language he didn't know how to read. Crispin sensed that the object looked familiar to him. "I--I've never seen this before in my life? What is it??"
         "Records show that you stole the medallion represented by this here diagram. Do you know how valuable it is?"
         "I don't know what you're talking about...I didn't steal anything!" Crispin grinned mischievously when he heard the man's heartbeat quicken over the words "I didn't steal."
         "Yes, you have. Your DNA was all over the crime scene."
         "My DNA... how did you even get my DNA?"
         "We were monitoring you," said Crispin. "I swabbed your beer glass at the bar last week."
         The man's heart beated faster, faster, faster.
         With a sly smile on his face, Crispin took a step farther, and gazed deeply into the man's eyes.
         "You will hand over the medallion--right now--or I will rip your throat out."
         The man gulped.
         "I said... you will hand it over!"
         Suddenly, Crispin was jolted by a sharp pain in his gut. He looked down to see a small wooden stake protruding from his flesh. He ripped it out, wincing. Thankfully, he looked up just in time to see the man trying to escape. It took Crispin half a second to appear in front of him, stopping him in his tracks.
         "Clever, clever boy," said Crispin. "You thought you could get away." He looked at the man's hands, and yanked the crested ring that was on his finger right off, and threw it to the ground.
         "Wh-What are you going to do to me?"
         "You know," he whispered. He looked at the ring that was sitting in the grass. "That ring won't do you any good, now, will it?" Crispin gripped the man's neck, and twisted it with such force that the man was dead in an instant. He slumped lifelessly to the ground.
         When Crispin heard the screams that followed, his first instinct was to...

         Dorothy cleared her throat. "Well, if you're gonna stay, could ya please close the door? Looks like rain out there."
         The man did as requested and approached the desk. "I need a room. Please."
         "We got plenty o' rooms. How many nights?"
         "Just this one."

The more money she can get, the longer the motel stays in business. She had to keep it running for her late beloved husband.
         She sighed. "That'd be $30.99." As the man forked over the change, Dorothy watched his face. There was something strange about him, but she couldn't quite put a finger on it.
         Dorothy usually had an excellent "people instinct", as she called it. She almost always knew what a person was like just by looking at his face, and she just knew that there was something off about this fellow. The way he held himself, the way he spoke, the hollow look to his eyes. Something was strange, and Dorothy wasn't so sure about lending him a motel room.
         Still, she pushed that thought aside; she needed all the money she could get.
         "If I could just see your ID now, I'll get you your key and you'll be all set," she said a bit shakily.
         "Ma'am? Are you frightened?" He feigned concern. Dorothy knew it was false. The man was just... he was frightening. She was frightened.
         "No sir. I-I just need ta see your ID!"
         "Well, I don't have one."
         "I'm sorry, but I can't let you have a room without an I--D---" Her breath was caught off by a firm hand clenched to her throat. She grasped onto the man's cold, dead-feeling hand, trying to pry his fingers free.
         He got close to Dorothy's face, gazing deeply into her eyes. She felt a pulling sensation on her mind as the man told her once again that he had no ID; he demanded to be allowed a room anyway.
         Without hesitation, Dorothy gives him the key to the room, although she didn't want to, although she fought against his mysterious persuasive power. I'd been waiting in the hospital for hours. Every time I made eye contact with one of the nurses, they turned away. Their expressions told me nothing.
Where was my sister?
Suddenly the automatic doors flew open and an ocean of rain poured in. Looking around the corner, I searched for my father's face.
He said he'd be here soon. Is he hurt? Is he with the little kids? Where's Violet?
The man who walked in wasn't my father. No, he had long hair that my mother would have attacked with the kitchen scissors upon first glance. It must have been brown at some point, but the hurricane whirling just outside had turned it a sinister shade of tar. He was holding a woman clumsily in his over-sized red hands. The woman appeared to be asleep, and she was very beautiful. Her sugar-spun hair was the color of Dad's corn on the cob and it curled in every direction. Her face was dotted with freckles which accentuated her ski-slope nose and full lips. Her lashes were like a fairy tale princess's and her eyes were shut tight so I was left to wonder the pigment of her irises.
The man abruptly shook the woman. "She needs help! Somebody help her!!" The receptionist, D'Ann, placed a comforting chocolate hand on his shoulder in a genuine attempt to comfort and calm him but the lunatic shrugged her off. "Don't help me! It's my wife!" D'Ann signaled for several doctors equipped with a stretcher to help the woman to a room.
As they wheeled her away, the man tried to follow and D'Ann stopped him. "I'm sorry, you're going to have to wait out here." She gestured over to the area where I sat and they both looked past me as if I was invisible.
After years of wishing to be invisible, THIS is when my wish is granted?
Mystery Man, quieter now that his companion was in professional care, slumped into a blue sofa across from me. I couldn't help it, I stared.
"What are you lookin' at, kid?"
"I'm not a kid," was my genius response.
He seemed to crack a smirk at that. "Oh yeah? How old are you now? Seven? Eight?"
"I'm thirteen," I answered seriously.
"Oh," he seemed embarrassed. Good; did I really look seven or eight as a nervous wreck?

"Now nobody's gonna move or talk until I'm gone, you hear?" He jerked from side to side looking each individual in the eye with a threatening look while I struggled in vain to squirm away. He frowned, "Good. That's more like it."

I'm no sucker. 'Taylor."
"Good, now I'm Ryan," I couldn't tell if he was lying too, he matched my acting abilities, "and you and I are going to get into that car over there and pretend like none of this ever happened."
I looked over to where he'd pointed. Sure enough there was a new green Camaro parked up against the curb. I couldn't help but think how much that car would've impressed my brother.
Would I ever see Tristan again? What about Dad? Or Violet, Xylina, Joy, Jade, Christopher, and Kainen?
Where was Violet?
Then I noticed the woman leaning against the Camaro. She had sleek, straight blond hair that was chest-length and dazzling blue eyes hidden beneath sharp green eyeglasses. As a matter of fact, I could've sworn I saw a smile played at the corners of her lipstick-smeared mouth.
Uh-oh.
This guy had a partner in crime.

Mike took a deep breath and stepped out of the shadows and towards Trevor.

As he neared, Trevor whipped around to face him. Mike had no clue how he could had heard him through the storm, but he must have sensed him because he was there, no longer watching the cabin but glaring at Mike threateningly.

"Mike, what are you doing here?"

Mike narrowed his eyes. "We'll this IS my sister's cabin." he growled

Trevor sized him up. Mike's spine prickled but he forced himself to stand his ground. He could sense the tension in the air. A fight would be coming soon, and he would be the one to start it. No one was going to hurt her sister, even if she does deserve it.

"What the hell do you want?" Mike continued, his voice loud and firm. Suddenly, thunder clapped above their heads, so loud that it sounded like the heavens were being torn in two. He flinched, and Trevor smiled.

"Scared of a little thunder, eh Mike?" he laughed. "But, then again, you were always a wimp."

Anger whelmed inside Mike, more so than before. "Shut the hell up and leave my sister alone!" he yelled, his hands balling into fists. His voice sounded pretty vicious, and that satisfied him. Who's scared now?

Trevor sneered. "Hey, I can do whatever I want to with Vanessa. Actually, she seems to like it that way. I think she has a motto, 'Give the boys what they like'? Is that it? 'Cause she sure lived up to it -- "

Mike shot forward and grabbed him by the scruff of his shirt and pushed him up against a tree, his face furious.

"You stay away from my sister or else -- "

Trevor's laugh interrupted him. "Or else what? You're going to call my parents?" Even though he was being gripped by Mike and was in threat of being hit, he could still find something smart to say. "Why don't you just punch me already? Be a man and do something for once. Come on, punch -- "

Before Trevor could finish Mike raised his fist and drew back. This was it. He was going to hurt Trevor, and oh, would it feel great. All his strength and anger was built into this one punch and as he was about to swing it at his face, something shot into him and knocked him down.

Pain seared his shoulder as he landed on a gnarled root. His teeth gritted and his hand instantly gripped his shoulder. Furious, he looked up, ready to face his attacker...

But no one was there. No one except Trevor, who was leaning against the tree, dazed and staring in front of him in shock.

Mike was confused. If he hadn't pushed him, then who...? He turned his head and followed Trevor's gaze, and his eyes widened

A man stood there, a few yards away, half obscured by the trees. He was tall with long hair and dark, calculating eyes. His face was unnaturally pale and purple bags could be seen below his eyes. Mike had never seen him before, and from the looks of it, neither had Trevor.

The man smiled. It sent shivers down his spine. "Gentlemen, Gentlemen," he said, his arms raising welcomingly. His voice was calm and smooth, confidence ringing in every word. "Don't fight over dear Vanessa! There's plenty of her to go around -- "

Trevor, being the idiot he was, stormed up to him. The man just watched him as he neared. "Who the hell are you?" Trevor demanded. He was face to face with him now, his chest puffed out and his fists clenched. "Oh, wait! Let me guess! You're another one of 'dear Vanessa's' toys?"

The man just smiled, obviously amused. "You make it sound so dirty. No no, not a toy, my dear friend -- " Trevor scoffed at the word friend, " -- but a... blood mate."

Blood mate? What was this guy talking about? Trevor seemed to be infuriated by these words, even though Mike was certain he didn't know what he meant anymore than him.

"You stay away from her, you hear? And tell those other scum bags too, back from where ever the hell you came from!"

The man looked down at him, his smile still on his face. "Oh, I'm not going anywhere," he said, his voice becoming deadly. "And neither, I'm afraid, are you."

The man suddenly grabbed Trevor's shoulders before he could react and, to Mike's utter horror, leaned down and bit his neck.

And that's when the screaming started.

It was big, maybe a .45 Rai thought, & the fact that the guy was wearing sunglasses made him think of the old Dirty Harry movies.

"I expect you'll be wanting us to make your day next, right?"

No answer.

The tall guy raised his arm, and fettered his grip. Rai watched his hand, time slowing to a crawl - waiting for the man to tense up, knowing that in the split second before the shot he would strike. Low. Hopefully knocking him over, but at least making him miss the shot.

His mind, like a steel-trap, planned the strike the second the gun was drawn. But that was his way, cold, calculated. On the outside relaxed & free-wheeling like a starving artist, inside a predator, ready to strike - or in this case, defend the girl.
Wind whipped rain against the windows. Rai's calves tightened. The tendons on the hand wrapped around the revolver grew taught.

Breathing stops.
This is it.

He had to admit, his chances of saving Vanessa in the cabin were only fifty-fifty, but Maryse had gotten her out safely, even if it meant she was going somewhere even more treacherous. Rai pulls up short, confused.

"Aila, what's wrong--"

The hiss of a knife brushed against his cheek as it whistled by, leaving a line of red in its wake. Rai turns, catching the barest glimpse of the attacker, before a kick sends him into the darkness. Before she can say anything else, Zanthe holds another knife out, pointing at her neck. "Now," he starts, "I don't remember saying whose side I was on, do you?"

Aila instinctively crouches into a defensive stance. "You wouldn't… You know Vanessa too. We have to find her and stop Maryse!"

This pulls Zanthe up short. "Maryse? Who's that?" He quickly composes himself again, adjusting the knife. "Nevermind. I don't care about Vanessa either. It's you I've come for."

"What?" Aila finds herself frozen again with surprise. Then realization dawns on her. "The Trials…"

"Correct. You will return with me this time, Aila." He twirls the knife lazily. "You can't afford not to."

"But, Zanthe, don't you see? Vanessa is a part of this too!" Aila becomes frazzled. "We have to rescue her because she is an important piece of the Trials as well! It's not just about you and me anymore!" Zanthe considers her words, then slips the knife back into his coat.

"I don't know who this "Maryse" person is, but I know where Vanessa is going. We'll work from there." The rain dies down as Aila returns her arrow to the quiver, gray eyes searching his face.

12221.content:
Vanessa fought against her ties. The rope was tightly bound around her hands and feet, and was cutting into her skin. She grimaced by the pain, but she had other things to worry about. Jake was leaning against the fireplace mantel, watching her struggle with dark amused eyes.

"There's no use," he said, the corner of his mouth lifting into a mocking smile. It sent a shiver down her spine. "There's no escaping now... besides, of course, you agreeing to tell us where he is."

Vanessa glared at him threateningly. "Never!" she growled. "You will never find him! I'd rather die than tell you!"

Jake's grin grew. "That can be arranged," he crooned. Icy fear washed over her as she stared into his brown eyes. His words had been so matter-of-factly and simple that it seemed to slice through all the hopes she had of surviving. He was telling the outmost truth, and that terrified her. "We can always ask you brother."

"No!" she practically shouted. Angry tears swam in her eyes. "Michael has nothing to do with this!"

Jake laughed scornfully. "We'll see about that."

Suddenly a knock came from the door. Her eyes widened in fear. 'This was it,' she thought, tears streaming down her ashen cheeks. 'There's no way out. I'm going to die... I'm going to die...'

The chair she was tied in was faced away from the kitchen, where the front door was, so she has no possible way of seeing the person until he comes and stands next to her. The wait was agonizing. She was finally going to find out who her enemy was at last. All this time Jake had been stalking her, keeping an eye on her for him. Jake had betrayed their relationship for this man... if he had ever though of it as a relationship at all.

She couldn't believe she had gotten herself into this. Her brother Mike... her dear, dear brother Mike, had warned her to stay away from him -- that he was dangerous. Was he ever right. She had told him that she could be friends with whoever she liked. Turns out Jake had only been so nice to her for the past month because he was trying to obtain information about her cousin Blake, who was in the witness protection program. He had betrayed a large mafia group that was trying to get there hands on a lot of gold, one of them being a golden egg that apparently was worth millions of dollars. Blake worked as a spy, along with his good friend Trevor, and had corrupted the group, but since it was so large, not everyone was caught. It got a new leader, and that very man was entering my cabin.

"Finally." She heard Jake's voice from where he was in the kitchen. "Do you know how hard it was to bind her? It would have been nice if I had had some help."

The other man didn't say anything but strolled through the kitchen to the den, still behind her. He sounded close. Vanessa stifled back a cry.

The leader spoke quietly to Jake for a moment, her words almost too faint to hear. Vanessa caught a few words though, and they were "Finnish it".

All her life, she had never been so scared. Her very existence rested on this moment, and this moment alone. She was either going to die or betray her cousin who she loved with all her heart and have him murdered. Never again would she see Blake's smiling face, or Mike's, or her mother and father. Never again would she play with her dog or spend time with her friends, Anne or Robyn or Trevor.

Trevor.

The boy she loved with all her heart since she was twelve. Her high school sweetheart and loving boyfriend. He would die too, if she gave Blake away. They were working together when they were in the mafia, and had brought it down together. They would surely want revenge on him too.

Vanessa's vison blurred again as a new wave of tears spilled. She didn't want her life to end. She loved the world and didn't want to leave. But she would have too. She could not betray them.

It took a moment for her vision to sharpen again and for the world around her to return. Her tears subsided and as she blinked the rest away she realized that the man was standing right in front of her.

And it was Trevor.

122221122112222.content:
Silence was spread across Tentiron, the ruined city crushed by King Raling during the Darkened War. A small clunk, the sound of some rocks crumbling, before a boy of only fifteen leapt from one side of a building to the other, through a gaping hole in the side caused by a small bomb. His very long staff quickly collapsed in on itself as he pulled it back up with him, and he landed on his feet in the center of a road blocked off by rubble.

Slow clapping.

"Great job, Trinki," the other boy said, sixteen years old.

"I call you by your name, I have the right to be called by mine."

Srenti chuckled. "Says the guy who has a spring-loaded extendable pole vault."

"Hey, just because I found it first..." Entrinkil replied to his brother.

Srenti stood up from the rock pile where he was sitting, stretched, and said, "Well, maybe it's my turn to find something. There IS an old weapons store down 85th a bit that we haven't raided yet." The section of street they were on was at the corner of 85th Ave. and Main St. and had already been raided for all its supplies by them.

They currently lived in the old café that had one of the only open doors. They stocked their food in the bathroom and spent most of their time out raiding the ruins of the old city. One skyscraper a few blocks down even had working computers, although no Internet. The boys spent their nights hiding away inside the café, with the pile of rubble they had built the only thing keeping the wolves that hunted at that hour from walking through the giant hole in the window and eating some dinner. Both brothers were very athletic, and had been electronically modified for an environment not unlike the popular game Mirror's Edge. Or, at least, it was popular before Raling took over and the New World Order came into effect. That was also the time when all of such modification technology was destroyed by an airstrike and a few missiles, bombs, and grenades. People had built barricades and walls out of trash and rubble and signs, which made a perfect environment for the two parkour artists.

The boys made their way back to the old café, quickly sprinting and making use of things like fire escapes and traffic lights to speed up their journey. However, when Srenti scrambled over the rocks and Entrinkil leapt through the hole in the building, the two brothers were face to face with...
1222211221122221.title: To the weapons store we go!

It stood, in between the piles of rocks and broken buildings that let to the café. The one street section that Srenti and Entrinkil lived on. The one. There was no possible way that the boys could make it to the building before they were attacked. It growled at them, its eyes red, its teeth bared. It wasn't going to give up shelter that easily. The wolf shook the blow off, and leapt at Srenti before he could fire off another stone at the wolf. Srenti went under, engaging the wolf in hand-to-hand. Well, that is, the best that he could. He felt the warmth of the creature's fetid breath as he struggled to keep its paws up. If the creature was able to land its front limbs, Srenti would be a goner. Before the giant dog had a chance to land another bite, Srenti saw Entrinkil sprinting toward him with half of a metal pole- the one that had been snapped. The wolf howled in pain, and rolled off of Srenti, falling back down the pile of rubble. Entrinkil, even with his horrendous aim, had jammed the pole directly into the wolf's eye.

The large canine whimpered in pain, but quickly stood again. Blood trickled from its right eye as it glared. Srenti and Entrinkil had the high ground, and knew it. The giant wolf growled, in a fruitless attempt to scare them off. That thing would fight until its dying day, however, and before the brothers knew it, it had jumped again. It still had enough energy to make another power leap! This time it knocked Srenti off of the rock pile, pushing him into the street. Entrinkil screamed as Srenti's back smacked against the ground. Cracking noises. The wolf bore down, tearing a chunk of flesh from the older boy's cheek and chomping it. Entrinkil walljumped off of the side of one of the skyscrapers they were near and, using the power of gravity, bore down onto the wolf, still clutching half of his pole.

As a blue she-wolf, that walked on two legs, Lupus was feared by many, and worshipped by some. The poor girl didn't want the attention, all of it simply because she was different. Many called her an act against nature. Others named her their goddess.
It was murder on the nerves.
The ones that hated her were trying to either kill her, or force her to undergo testing in laboratories. Basically, any God-fearing person held a gun to her chest.
It made her fearful of humans.
However, women seemed more often than not, open-minded about her, and took her in when she needed protection. That was how she grew up, suckling on mothers along with their children, or cowering from their fathers.
Her own parents.....she never remembered them. They must have either gone into hiding, or died.
She never thought that they would abandon her.
How could someone leave their own child for the vultures, even if it wasn't human?
Lupus had gotten her name from the first woman to take her in, a nice plump lady that lived in the country. She hid the young pup in the haymow of her barn, and played with her whenever her husband was busy and away from the farmyard. She had one child at the time, a baby she had also rescued. She and her husband had adopted her so they were able to keep her.
But now, Lupus was on her own.
Turning a corner, she walked on the sidewalk, chin up, shoulders back. She wasn't going to let anyone touch her, not today.
Many people stared.
Most stopped what they were doing to watch her.
Lupus' tail wanted to curl up under her legs, but she wouldn't let it. She must not show fear.
That's when she heard the scuffling going on inside the country-store to her right.

Vibrations shot up his backside. His mind froze in what he expected to be his last moments of life. "What are the chances?" He thought, "It was good while it lasted." Nothing happened.

Opening his eyes up to the raining night he leaned back against the tree.

"Vrrrrrr," came a sound accompanied by another vibration.

"Wait!" Trevor hissed. Mike didn't seem to hear.

"View Missed Call. Low Battery."

"Home - 555-0437" it read. Steve's home number! If he could get a hold of Steve, he could get him to contact the police and maybe get some help up here.

"Calling," the phone read. Ringing. Trevor looked back towards the cabin, but Mike was nowhere to be seen.

Click. "Hello?" Came Steve's voice.

"Steve, thank god you picked up the phone!"

"Hey, do you have my phone?"

Trevor stood dumbstruck. "Who the hell cares. Look, I need you to call the police and come up to the Rental Lodge on the mountain. All Hell has broken loose and I think Mike might be planning something stupid!"

She'd barely said more than a few incoherent words the whole time but when the door flew open and a male voice called out to her, she muttered the name 'Mike' and something about 'anti-vegetarians.'

Joey leapt from the chair, his first instinct to leave before this new arrival could question him. Instead, he straightened his jacket and tie and then crossed the small room, exiting into the outer hall. He could see that the front door was swung open and a dark-haired man, a couple of years older than Joey and soaked to the bone, stood just inside. Taking him in with his eyes, Joey spotted the rock held in his hand.

"Where's my sister?" Mike seethed at Joey.

He was about to try and calm Mike down when the sound of breaking glass interrupted them. The bedraggled mess of a man, still clutching his rock, followed as Joey darted back to the room he had just left. It was a shambles. A side-table had been toppled beside the armchair and the curtains blew wildly into the room as the wind and rain assailed them through the broken shards of glass that used to be a window. A dozen or more books lay scattered and strewn on the floor, having fallen from the table under the sill and several drops of blood marred its surface.

Of the girl, there was no sign.

"Where's my sister?" the Mike asked again, with more anger in his voice this time.

It took Joey a moment to recover his senses before replying dumbly as he pointed into the storm, "Out there."

"Joey, what the hell?" another voice spoke up behind them, " I ask you to do one simple thing and you screw it up! What the hell, man?"

Alex was in the middle of soldering the wires for a half-completed prosthetic when she was interrupted by a sudden assault of hard rock music from her phone. She blinked absently, her deep brown eyes unfocused as she drew herself back out of her work. The phone rang a for another two rings before she finally realized what the painful cacophony meant. Another call from Ryan. Alex glanced back at the half-completed prosthetic on the work table uncertainly, then sighed and reached for the iPhone that was buried beneath a pile of diagrams and tools. Even though she was extremely tempted to just ignore him and continue on with her project, if she ignored him he would keep on calling until she picked up. Better to just get it over with. She picked up and put him on speaker as she continued on with her soldering.

"What is it?" she said brusquely, "I'm very busy, so keep it short. What do you want now? That decryption device you wanted isn't going to be going for any less than what I told you before, and I ain't bargaining."

"I remember you said that you install prosthetics before," Ryan's familiar voice came over from the other line, but it sounded strained. "Do you have a medical license?"

The soldering iron froze over a neural processing connection. "I do install prosthetics, but I don't have a medical license. I know all the material, so you think I have seven, ten years to waste?" She rolled her eyes. "Why?" He was probably up to something again, though she didn't understand why he was suddenly asking about a medical license. He never cared about licenses and what not before, so why did he start now?

She heard him sigh, and there seemed to be what sounded like sirens in the background. "That's better than nothing," he said hastily. "I'm coming over in 10 minutes. See you."

"Wait. What--"

He hung up on me. She thought in disbelief. Alex glared at the phone for a moment before scowling down at the still-incomplete project she was working on. It sounded like he was stuck in some trouble again with his job as usual. But if he was coming over, then that meant that she probably wouldn't have the time to finish this today. She sighed then started to clear her things off her desk. She'd have to finish it next time.

After clearing her desk by hurriedly throwing her tools back into their boxes and setting the prosthetic back on top of another pile of equipment next to her desk, she took a cursory glance around her room. Cabinet and desk drawers with tools and papers emptied out onto the ground reminded her suddenly that she was still in the middle of cleaning. I got distracted again. She sighed. Cleaning up always took so much time; it was already the fifth day in a row, but it looked no better. In fact, it looked even worse than it did before she ever cleaned it. Perhaps she should just give up. She really didn't mind it the way it is, and she always could find her things despite it not being the most organized. The only real reason she even attempted to clean up the place was because the rare visitor that came here always complained about how messy it is. 12433.content:
Trevor watched from the shelter of an oak tree as Mike turned around and trudged back towards the direction of the road. 'Good,' he thought. His brown hair clung to his forehead and he brushed it away with his hand as a shiver crawled down his spine. The temperature was dropping and the wind was becoming stronger. It pelted his already soaked back, and he knew that he would have to get to the lodge soon, or freeze.

Mike had been watching him, and Trevor knew that as long as he was there, he would have no chance at getting to the cabin safely. Now that he was gone, it gave him room to breathe. He must have given up in trying to protect his sister, but that was alright. One last person for her to rely on.

Trevor turned back to the cabin and was about to head that way when somthing caught his eye—a shadow moving through the trees.

He halted. 'What was that?' he thought. He stared at where the shadow disappeared through the rainy night. He remained like that for a moment longer, his eyes wavering and his mind reeling, but when nothing happened, he shook his head and started toward the lodge again. His mind must have been playing tricks on him.

He was a short distance from his hiding place and was pushing back a low branch when all of a sudden another shadow shot past him a few meters ahead. Trevor stopped, the branch still in his hand.

'What the hell?' he thought, suddenly scared. Not wanting to show it he yelled against the wind, "Who's there? Show yourself!"

Right on cue and person strolled smoothly out, light on its feet. It was a woman wrapped in a wet cloak. Her long platinum hair was plastered around her face and rain dripped from the tip of her nose. Trevor thought that she should have been miserable, but instead she stood before him proudly. The storm seemed to do nothing to her at all.

The woman spoke. "Come with me." Her voice was as soft as velvet and as beautiful too, but rang through the storm with such strength and confidence that he couldn't help but be a little nervous. Who was she and what did she want?

Without checking to see if he was following, the woman turned away and hurried into the rain and out of sight, away from the lodge and the road. She wanted him to go deeper into the woods!

Trevor didn't know what to do. The woman was like nothing he had ever seen. She didn't seem... human, but something more. He had never been scared of the other gender, but now... he wasn't so sure. When she had strolled out, she was so light on her feet that they seemed not to hit the ground.

He looked down at his shoes and the trail of muddy prints he had left behind him. The ground was too soft. Any contact with it and your feet would sink in slightly. He looked back the way she went and couldn't find a single imprint. And something about her voice. It was too smooth, too powerful. Her presence was so reassuring yet unsettling . He didn't feel right when he saw her, yet he felt so right. He couldn't explain.

He remained there, unsure of what to do or where to go. He could forget about her and go to the lodge. He needed to do something there. He had a duty. Yet, curiosity pricked at him. Maybe he should follow her....

He turned around to glance back the way Mike went, towards the road. His car was waiting there. His warm car that would bring him back home.

Suddenly, another shadow fleeted away in the corner of her eye. Terror gripped him as he searched for it but it was gone again. He didn't know what to do. All he knew was that he couldn't stay here any longer….

"Hey! What are you doing here?" Rogan hissed, stepping slightly out of the shadows of a corridor. "You're not supposed to be-"

He broke off, looking quickly down the hallway. Closing his eyes for a moment, he listened- then turned wearily back. "If you want what's best for you, you'll follow me... but if you'd like, you can go on. It's your call." Shrugging unconcernedly, he spun on his heel and slunk back into the shadows without looking back.

As he crept along the dark hallway, he passed numerous ornate doors and passages, but ignored all of them, keeping his eyes trained on the ground. "Eh, they always find a way here... but they never listen," he muttered, impatiently brushing aside a lock of dark hair as he scanned the floorboards, narrowing his dark grey eyes. Stopping suddenly, he tapped his foot experimentally here and there until he heard the sound that he was looking for- a hollow echo. Dropping to his knees, he felt his way around with careful, gloved hands, then gave a grunt of effort as he hoisted a large portion of floor up and settled it gently against a wall. Giving a small sigh, he lowered himself into the passageway that he had just exposed, catching hold of and moving the floorboards over the hole once again.

Once he was safely in the passage, Rogan commenced to catch hold of something on a wall in the pitch black anteroom, wrenching it out with a burst of annoyance. "Feh," he grumbled as he snapped on the torch, illuminating a room full of dusty furniture. "It would've been easier to leave at once... but I had to stay in this godforsaken place... Ah well. The sooner I find it, the sooner I'll be out of here... maybe it was in that room? No, I've been there before... but maybe a library would have it in there- it should be the most natural place, after all..."

12521.content:
Mike followed the girl. He didn't know why, but something about the mysterious woman intrigued him. Was it her beautiful velvet voice, or the fact that everything about her screamed "immortal"?

The man halted suddenly. 'What the heck?' he thought, shaking his head disapprovingly. 'Immortal? What am I, nuts? There's no such thing as immortal. She's just... strange. That's all.'

Mike looked around him. Ominous black trees surrounded him, and rain pelted his back, sending shivers down his spine. Above him, thunder clapped -- right as a light forked from the sky and stuck a tree nearby on the ridge. He flinched. Where was he now?

He swiveled around, seeking out the lodge or the woman but found nothing. Nothing except the dark looming walls of the forest and the mountains.

Fear suddenly pricked at him. He was lost.

"Oh great!" he yelled, knowing that no one would be able to hear him. "Just great!" Anger pulsed through him as he kicked furiously at a tree root. Pain shot up his leg but he didn't care. "Now Vanessa could die and it'd be all my fault!"

Suddenly, a shape in front of him materialized out of the shadows. Mike stumbled back in terror. Was it Trevor? Had he heard him when he was watching him? If he had, then he had surely come to kill him. He was, after all, a threat to him. Mike clenched his fists as he tried to stand his ground without shaking. If he was going to die, he wasn't going down without a fight.

The person strolled swiftly out of the trees to stand mere feet from him. Mike almost sank in relief. It was the girl.

She smiled. "Follow me and I will lead you to your sister. But hurry," she said, while handing him something heavy. Mike looked down in surprise. A knife lay in his hands. "He is near," she warned gravely, her eyes serious. Without another word she turned around and hurried out into the storm.

'Can I trust her?' Mike wondered. He gripped the knife in his right hand and was about to follow her when suddenly he heard something or someone closing in behind him in the darkness....

125222212.content:
As I rang the doorbell, I could hear Elena speaking to someone. "You see," she said, "Some people still like to ring the bell. That's kinda how it works in this world." In this world? What the hell is she talking about?

When she opened the door, Elena looked frazzled. Her auburn hair frayed around her head, giving her a slightly orange halo. "Millie! Thank God you're here!"

She pulled me into a hug and whispered in my ear, "There's something really weird going on here. I need your help."

Pushing her away, I searched her face for a clue of what she was speaking. "What's going on?, Leny?" I scanned the hallway behind her and everything looked normal. Sure, a few of Matthew's toys lying on the floor, but that wasn't unusual. When she took my hand, hers was clammy, and it made me feel uncomfortable.

"Come with me," she said. Her voice was low, and she led me to Matthew's room. Shoving into the doorway, she said, "Look!"

Nothing untoward. Matthew lay fast asleep on his bed, more toys lay on the floor. But nothing in any way odd. I turned to Elena and shrugged my shoulders. "What?" I mouthed.

Elena jumped in front of me and said, "What the . . . ?" After a moment, she added, "Maybe they're in the living room now."

I followed her into the large, open plan living room/diner. It was empty. No sign of Mike or anyone else. "Well, that's strange she said," with her rubbing her chin. She continued through the whole house in that manner, until finally slumping in on of the wooden kitchen chairs.

"Sis, you're freaking me out now. What the hell is going on?" My sister was generally the better of us three girls at keeping it together. She chose a decent husband who would never cheat on her (like my husband, Ben) and would never spend all their money on horse races (like Fi's husband, Hal). No, Mike was a good one. Elena chose well. She did everything well, but now some thing I didn't understand was going on.

"They were here, Millie. The three of us spoke. Well, actually, they spoke and I listened. In Matthew's room and out into the hallway. Then you rang the bell, and now, where are they? They were here!" Her voice became increasingly high-pitched. "Here!" Her red face steamed as she swung around in a 360.

"Who, Leny?" I prayed she would answer Mike and that no-good sister of his, but I knew she wouldn't.

"Odaxitar and Mistfire."

My laugh was a reflex, and it was out before I could hold it in. "Sorry. It's just, Odaxitar and Mistfire? Really?"

She slammed her hand on the pine dining table, making me jump. "I know how crazy I sound!" she hissed. "I can hear me, too!"

"Okay. That's good. Then, what the hell are you talking about? Who is Odaxitar and Mistfire?"

Leaning in and speaking in hushed tones, she grabbed my wrist as she spoke. "That's just it. I don't know. Odaxitar, I think she's human. But she's kind of purple, so I'm not really sure. And Mistfire, she's not human. But she speaks. She's a creature who speaks. Very wise, she is."

I search for the trace of a smile in my sister's face. I need to know she is joking. I need to know she doesn't believe all of this crazy. But she is deadpan.

"And they were both here, you say?" Come one, Elena, not is the time to say the joke is one me!

Anne shivered. Her car had stopped smack in the middle of Nowheresville. Paul was waiting for her and there she was, in a stalled borrowed hatchback wondering if she should’ve taken a left instead. ‘Go right and you’ll never go wrong’ had never failed her before.

The fierce rain intimidated her but Anne knew that if she didn’t get back to the city before the worst part of the storm, she’d be sorry. Her lightweight car would get blown away along with the last shred of her credibility. Lifting a hand from the steering wheel, held the hair back from her forehead for a moment in an attempt to decide what to do.

Pulling her hair back into a rubber band, Anne sighed. Her father had taught her a few tricks, but she hoped they’d get the vehicle started. Buttoning her blouse the rest of the way up, she took a deep breath and opened the door into the rain.

Almost immediately she was pressed against the side of the car by the wind. “Boy, this is fun,” she said into the dark.

She managed to get the hood up and remain upright long enough to find her problem – a stuck accelerator spring, or that’s what she called the part. She toggled it and was just about to put the hood back down when she realized she wasn’t alone.

Jacketless, a man stood before her.

Regretting the waste of energy it would take to go try to help her out, Trevor sighed, but could do nothing else. He would never leave a woman alone and stranded without help in this weather, or in any weather.

Grabbing another handful of muddy grass to help stabilize his climb, Trevor headed in her direction. He was breathless by the time he reached her. The rain had concealed the sound of his footsteps. She turned with a start, wide-eyed at the sight of him.

13111111.content:
Trevor paused, too baffled by the situation to respond. He could not so much as think of a way to stall for the time he needed to make sense of things, so he just let the silence grow between them while the man stared. The masked stranger maintained a confident posture in perfect stillness, and exuded an air of dreadful finality that said, "So be it." As the moments crept along, the acute feeling that he wasn't getting out of here without a violent confrontation increased, so that he scarcely dared to breath, lest the slightest indication of intention signal the man to attack. It was like coming around a corner and surprising a viscious doberman. Although he strove for words of peaceful assurance what finally passed his lips was a question he immediately knew was the wrong thing to ask, "And what do you plan to do with her when you find her?"

His answer, although vague, carried a promise that Trevor knew was not given vainly. "Whatever I have to," he said. Then the gun, an hefty piece with a large bore came out from beneath his black jacket. "Now get in here if you want to live." When Trevor hesitated he added, "Come on, there's no time for foolishness."

Praying that Anne would keep still and get away unnoticed, he shut the door behind him carefully, never taking his eyes off of the gunman for fear of giving her away with even a moment's glance. Once the door was closed, it took a mighty effort on Trevor's part not to sigh with relief.

"Now get down those stairs," he pointed with his pistol to a trap door in the floor, thrown open to reveal only an inky black aperture. Beside it there was a kerosene lantern and a box of matches beside it. "I guess we're going after her together, eh?"

Trevor did what he was told, telling himself to just play it cool until he had an opening to get the gun or escape. He watched his hands trembled while he fumbled for a match, and he decided that escape was the better of the two options. But then what about Nikki? He had the feeling that this guy wanted a good deal more than her autograph. He supposed that was one of the risks of putting one of your sexiest pictures on your book jacket; she had known better than that. "There's a reason that vanity is one of the Seven Deadly Sins," he'd told her.

"What do you want?" he asked while he tried a second match, the first having broken off in his nervous grasp.

"It's not about what I want," he said cooly.

"Then who?"

The man chuckled a little before he answered. "Well, I guess it won't do any harm to tell you, since you'll be meeting him ... if I don't have to kill you first." He paused, waiting to see how Trevor would respond, once he had a moment to think about it. When he said nothing, the man took his silence for ignorance. "Oh come one, Trevor, you should know, being Nikki's boyfriend and all."

A sick feeling roiled around in his gut, as the man revealed intimate knowledge about them. So they'd been watched.

While Trevor got the wick to light and turned it up the man asked him with a note of derisive mirth in his voice, "Do you mean to tell me that she didn't even have the courtesy to tell you why she-," now he laughed abruptly. "Oh that's so sad. I'll bet you thought that she was the one too, didn't you? Let me ask you, do you even know her real name?"

Trevor didn't dare to give him an answer. Because he didn't want to hear such things, and because he had to check the rage that threatened to leap up in place of the fear. It could get him killed.

"Come on," the man said, almost jovially. "Down the stairs now boy. We find the girl and then you get to go meet the Wolf."

13111112.content:
Thinking she'd simply drop him off in the muddy driveway of the lodge, Anne put the little hatchback into reverse, held her foot on the brake and watched as Trevor hurried to the front door. He threw the door wide but stopped just outside of the doorway. That was odd.

Anne watched for another few seconds, but he didn't move. The noise from the windshield wipers and the heater vents made it impossible to hear if he was calling for Nikki or not. Anne could imagine Nikki, lounging on some large rustic couch before the fire telling Trevor that she didn’t know why he’d come and that he needed to leave.

Was it because the lights were out that he didn't go in? His posture was such that Anne was unsettled. The feeling she had made her foot heavy on the brake. "As soon as he goes into the lodge, I'll go on to find Jenna," Anne said, knowing she was talking just to calm the sudden jolt of nerves. It'd been years since she'd had been confronted with a situation that may be considered physically dangerous, but Anne knew, if anyone pushed her into a corner, her reflexes would take over and she'd be the only one to walk away unscathed.

Counting the wiper cycles as they swiped ice from the windshield, Anne placed her hand on the shifter, eyes still trained on Trevor's back. She had to find out what was going on. If Nikki was in trouble, Trevor would likely be a little more than just out of his element, he'd be in the way. The artsy fellow had likely never held a kitchen knife, let alone a hand gun or a switchblade. Tossing the shifter into park, Anne pulled the key from the ignition and reaching across the seat, she opened a small compartment in the dash where Paul said he kept his revolver. "Don't point it unless you are going to pull the trigger," he'd always said. Well, if Nikki or Trevor were in trouble, Anne was going to catch the intruder unawares and she’d need more than just a few choice words to convince him he was in the wrong line of work. She rarely let anyone know to what extent she could take care of herself, but her secret was about to be out.

She grabbed a black leather brass-buttoned jacket from the back seat. If she was going to go out tonight, she'd enjoy wearing her favorite jacket one last time. Anne checked the gun and shoved it into her back waistband. She sent up a prayer and then, putting the keys in her hip pocket, Anne exited the car, careful not to slam the door. Holding to the shadows, she slinked from one shadow to the other until her back lay flat against the damp side of the lodge. Quickly then, she ducked down and hurried along the side of the house and rounded to the back deck to look in a window.

The interior wasn't as dark as the night. It seemed Nikki had a fire burning in the fireplace. Anne saw a large flickering shadow cross the threshold of the room she was peering into and she froze, watching closely and listening to every sound, turning each one over in her mind and identifying them until she had focused in on the sound of two voices - both male. Trevor and some raspy spit-filled voice that made her skin crawl. She knew people who spoke like that - a mask often making their speech more difficult to understand, but she knew what he was saying and didn't like it. She didn't like it one bit.

The intruder didn't know where Nikki was? He had just showed his hand and Anne was about to take all of his cards for she saw movement across the room - it was a reflection of the firelight off something metallic that had shifted. Nikki had to be in that closet. Anne dropped down to squat below the window. She shook her head. Once the intruder started to look for her, he'd find her easily enough and then it’d be on. She shook her head again and said under her breath, “Everyone hides in the closet or under the bed. Come on Nikki. Couldn’t you have found a better hiding place than that?” Anne had to get inside, and fast.

Considering every angle before entering the back door, Anne realized the intruder would hear her. He'd not hear her enter the room of course, but once she was there, he'd hear her. She was dripping wet. Anne still didn't know exactly who she was up against, but she knew she'd risk being seen before she wanted to if she went in there dripping all over the floor and squeaking around in her squishy tennis shoes. She considered going back around the lodge and bursting in behind Trevor, acting innocent and like a blundering clumsy girl. That worked on occasion to keep the bad guy off balance, but only bad guys who Anne knew had no idea who she was. This intruder was a mystery. He could be anyone.

Anne decided to chance getting caught. She got to the back door, which was surprisingly unlocked. She removed her shoes and socks and then, pausing to listen waited for her chance. It came not thirty seconds later. Trevor must have said something that angered the intruder because he’d lost his cool and was yelling at Trevor about something he’d come to get from Nikki. She turned the knob, keeping low, Anne slipped into the kitchen. She squeezed water from her pony tail, dried her feet on the rug and then paused to listen again. Slipping soundlessly to the door, Anne mentally touched the gun that rested cold against the skin of her back. She was determined to remove the threat without using the garish weapon, but felt secure knowing it was there if she needed it.

Anne pressed an ear against the door. Trevor was saying something about not knowing what Nikki had taken from the intruder, but if the man would tell him what it was, Trevor would get it back for him.

“Do you think I’m stupid? The only reason you’re still standing is because I’m in a good mood tonight.” The masked man drew in a long snotty breath through his congested nostrils. The sound made Anne cringe. “If I tell you what it is, you’ll keep it for yourself.”

“No. I’d never do such a thing. It’s yours. There’s no way I’d want it for myself.”

“You puttin’ me down now?”

“What? No! I’m just saying-”

The man interrupted Trevor with a bizarre laugh. Now was as good a time as any. Anne peeked out of the door and into the living area. There they stood. Trevor had taken a few steps into the room, but he didn’t look like he was in distress, just upset. The intruder was a big man, probably eight inches or more taller than Anne. No biggie, she thought. The taller ones are easier to get off balance. The intruder cackled again and Anne took her chance. She scuttled into the room to rest behind the couch that flanked the intruder. Her back was to the fire and to the room she was sure Nikki was in.
