I heard the voices getting louder as I riffled through the drawers in the final room in the cabin. A few of the other has some clothes in them, but not many. The summer season was still a month away and most people don't spend too much time in these mountains during the rainy spring times, a fact the storm outside attested to.

Which begged the question why there were so many people here in the first place? This was supposed to her MY job. I'd have to take care of the others once I secured the-

"Bingo!" I whispered as my fingers came into contact with the cool metal of a locked box. I quickly snatched it out, wiggling out my lock picks from the pocket of my pants. I brushed a stray lock of hair out of my face, glad that it's orange color was more concealed than usual under the hood of my waterproof jacket. Skin-tight too. Latest model.

I played around with the lock for a moment, and smiled as the familiar click of the latch let me know the job was done. Pocketing my picks once more, I opened the small case and carefully removed the vial contained with it. I unzipped my coat, and slipped the vial safely between my natural cushions, and refastened the jacket carefully.

Now, to deal with the others.

I sneaked down the hall, careful not to make a sound. I came upon the other intruders in the front living room, though I remain in concealment for the moment to listen to their chatter.

"Listen! I'm being employed by one of the sniff biggest men in all of New York, and he sniff ain't employ no dullards!" The masked mammoth was saying.

I rolled my eyes. Oh yes. so that's why you speak so eloquently! And if there's anyone bigger than you, tubby, I'll give up my commission And such a ...lovely....cold you seem to have. I thought dryly to myself. People didn't call me Queen Snarker for nothing.

"Fine! Just tell me where Nicki is and what you want from her, and then you can get out of here and back to the city, no problems, no cops. But where. is. Nicki?" The younger man's tone had gone serious and from my position in the hall, I could just barely see his eyes in the mirror. Dark eyes. Intense. And wet. This guy looked about as waterlogged as Niagara Falls. Oh? And what was that hiding behind the couch? I stretched my neck forward just a bit and smiled. Some crafty young girl was hiding behind the couch, looking ready to lunge at one of the men, though I wasn't sure which. I'd vote for the fatty. The other one was too close. She'd have taken her shot by now.

"I don't know where your girl is!" The fat one yelled, breaking into a coughing fit. I rolled my eyes again. He gave us professionals a bad name.

"Then what do you want? Maybe I can find it for you!" The young one too another step closer, and the fatty fingered something in his wait. Probably a stun gun or some lame toy.

"I...I ain't supposed to sniff tell no one." He shifted his immense weight uneasily.

"Please. I promise not tell a soul. All I want is Nicki's safety!" He looked about as earnest as a puppy..... a drowned puppy. Man! Was this guys swimming before he came here?

"I... I'm lookin' for some sorta present she got from sniff her dad or something. It's in a metal box, and sniff it's supposed to be some sort of scientific sniff thing, and I had it, and I was sniff gonna turn it in for a reward, and she took it and sniff I gotta get it back or else the Boss ain't gonna be happy." Was I in the mood for some role-playing and a grand exit? Or perhaps a quite exit would be best considering... my luggage.

With a deafening scream, Anne hopped on to the intruder's back. Caught by surprise, the attacker instantly fell over. She heard his head slam onto the wood floor. She was certain he was unconscious. Slowly standing up, she exclaimed, "Well, that was easier than I first thought."

Trevor was in a state of shock. Anne took him down in only seconds! His mind was racing. Their objective now was to find Nikki.
Trevor suggested they skimmed through the house. Anne rolled her eyes and muttered, "Have you ever seen a scary movie? The victim always hides in a closet or under the bed. Let's go."

The two strolled into the dark bedroom. It was eerily quiet. The floorboard moaned along with every step. Anne spotted the antique closet that look as if it belonged in the 1800's. When they stopped moving, the could hear a faint breath, shaking. Anne said, "Check under the bed. I'll get the closet."
Trevor bent down to peek under the four-poster. Seeing nothing, he got up and replied, "Nothing but dust bunnies." Anne nodded, but was silent. She was certain her friend was now in the closet.

Anne whispered, "Nikki, are you in there? It's me, Anne, and Trevor. You're safe. Everything's okay." Out of the blue, Nikki burst out of the closet and gave Anne a hug. With the commotion, the floor seemed unstable, as if it could collapse at any moment.

Trevor noticed this, and started to tip-toe out of the room. He explained what he felt to the others, but Nikki responded, "No duh! This cabin is really old. It's been like this since I started coming here. There's nothing to worry about, trust me." Trevor was still worried. After a minute of them calming down, Trevor knew this old room couldn't hold up for much longer. He had been studying architecture for a year, and knew this wasn't good.

Anne saw a crack starting to form on the floor. She stated, "Oh boy. That can't be good. Get out, now!"

The floor boards squealed and quickly began to splinter. Before they even thought to move the floor gave out and Anne, Trevor and Nikki plunged into the darkness below. They hit the ground not too far below, roughly thirteen to fifteen feet below the floor. Though it wasn't a painless fall, no one was injured.

         "Everything is NOT okay!" Nikki whined as she began to sob quietly to herself.

         Trevor didn't hesitate, and quickly began to search his pocket for a lighter. He found it and sparked a small flame to wave around in hopes of figuring out just where they had landed. He waved the flame around frantically, trying his best to illuminate the room. By the looks of it, they had landed in a cement-floored basement, probably used for storage or something. There were boxes placed here and there, nothing too suspicious.

         "I don't like the looks of this place..." Anne muttered, stepping closer to Trevor and Nikki.

         Nikki continued to sob softly to herself, freaked out beyond comprehension. Anne noticed Nikki had latched onto Trevor's arm, clinging to him out of terror. Despite Nikki's emotional turmoil, Anne couldn't help but be a little sickened by that- Nikki should have never gotten together with him. Anne still couldn't get over her opinion- Trevor was just some jerk who had never called her back.

         Anne began to trail a little further behind them, still following the light from Trevor's lighter. This day was just not at all what she had been expecting. She had been planning to head home, feed her cat, put on some comfy pajamas, and eat ice cream in front of the the TV, but no- that wasn't happening. Not today, not with Trevor and Nikki.

         Suddenly, something dropped down on Anne's shoulder. She shuttered in instant shock and let out a blood-curdling scream- her second scare today.

1311112.content:
"Hey, Trevor! I was talking to..." Anne stopped speaking abruptly and stared. It couldn't be. There was no way!

Anne started to tremble as she took in the scene. Nicki was no where to be seen, but in the middle of the dark sparsely furnished room stood a man wearing some kind of dumb mask that had haunted her dreams for years. He wore a pair of black leather gloves too. The only reason Anne noticed was because he held a shiny silver six-shooter in one of those gloved hands and a rather mean looking Bowie knife in the other hand. The knife glinted in the light that shown from a flashlight that lay on the floor. All of these details, Anne noticed in a millisecond.

Trevor stood stock still in front of Anne. She couldn't tell what he was thinking, but Anne could tell he had instantly gone into combat mode. She figured he was assessing the situation just as she had been, but didn't know for sure what he'd do until his hand found her elbow. Paniced adrenaline laced her quickened pulse at the touch and she heard him speak slowly. "Run. Don't look back. Run."

His fingers let go of her arm and when she didn't instantly turn to go, he shoved her out of the doorway. Anne fell back off the porch and into the stinging rain. She scrambled up and ran, clumsy, falling, muddy. She finally got back to the car, fumbled with the keys a bit before getting them into the ignition and then threw the shifter into reverse. A second or so later, the hatchback was tearing down the muddy dirt road. She yanked her purse up into the passenger seat and felt around in it for her cell phone, praying all the while that she'd have at least one bar of service out here in the boonies. If the police knew the serial killer known as Mr. Predator was standing in the lodge at this moment, they'd be falling over themselves to get the first crack at him.

Anne flicked open her cell, not bothering to look to see if she had service, and held down the nine key. Click, click, click, click, ring, sssssssssss. Ok, so no service. Anne had mind to throw the phone out of her window, but she wondered if that one blip of a ring she'd heard would mean she'd be able to send a text message. She glanced at the phone for a second, but that was all it took. The hatchback started to skid in the loose gravel and began to slide in the curve of the road. With fingers already shaking, Anne tried to turn into the skid to right herself, but it was too late. Before she knew it, the car was in a rather deep ditch with fast running icy water.

Anne pulled the car away, kicking up mud behind her. The pair sat in silence, neither of them wanting to give in and be the one who backed down. They came to a fork in the road, and Anne flicked the right turn signal.

"What are you doing?" asked Trevor. "I thought we were going to the lodge to get Nicki."

"Yeah, we are," she said. Her voice was clipped and she didn't take her eyes off the road.

"Good. Then, we need to head in the right direction," he said, flicking the signal to indicate left.

"What the hell are you doing? Never, ever touch my car hen I'm driving. Got it?"

He huffed and folded his arms over his chest. "Fine. But we have to get to Nicki. I've been to the lodge, like, a million times. I know the way. Trust me, Anne. Please."

Anger bubbled inside her, and she flicked her eyes to Trevor, then back to the road. "Okay." As she turned left, she pulled the car onto another dirt track. "Seriously? The car will get stuck again, or blow up from all the mud, or something."

After a long pause, Trevor sucked a whistle of air through his teeth. "Yes, you could be onto something there. Hmm." He rubbed his chin as he thought. "Right. You're going to have to park up right here, and we'll walk the rest of the way. The lodge is only just around that bend up there."

Pulling the car onto the side of the road, Anne sighed. "You want us to walk? In this weather!" She gesticulated with wild hands. "We'll get blown off our feet the second we get out of the car!"

"We won't. Not if we hold onto each other."

Shooting him an angry look, Anne shook her head. "No way. You go. You walk on your own. I'm driving there."

"We don't have time for all this arguing, Anne!" For the first time since he climbed into her car, trevor raised his voice. "Nicki is in danger. We have to get to her, like, yesterday!"

"What?" She shifted her body, so that it faced him. "What do you mean: danger?"

"Oh, okay. You know what Nicki is like. She gets involved with the wrong people, over and over again. And then, when she does, she cheats on them or steals from them, or does something stupid to make them want her dead."

She hated to admit it about her friend, but Trevor had a point. Nicki had always been the same, even in school. As she nodded, a feeling of trepidation settled in her stomach.

"Yeah, well this time, it's a doozy. The guy she's been seeing for the last three months is some big time criminal. He has links to some very dangerous people. And my sister—my stupid, little sister—just happened to uncover the code to his safe. While he was in the shower, she put that knowledge to use. Inside, she found ten bundles of $5,000. She didn't just take one, which might not have been missed. Oh no, she took them all, and promptly left the apartment to go on a spending spree. But the money was marked. And she got caught. She told the police exactly where she got the money from, only she said it was a gift. Of course, her boyfriend found out. Now, there is a price on her head."

This story had to be fake. This kind of thing didn't to people she new. She was a first grade teacher in the suburbs. "This is crazy, Trevor. Are you sure she hasn't been making up stories again? You know how wild her imagination is."

"It's true, Anne. Trust me on that. Now, are you going to walk with me to get her? She's hiding, but I think her ex might have tracked her down."

Fear choked Anne's throat, squeezing the wind out of her. She wanted to shout at Nicki about how stupid and selfish she had been, and if they got out alive, she would! But, they had been friends forever. There was no way Anne could leave her to die at the hands of this crook.

"Okay. Let's go."

"I won't harm you, or hurt you, or tease you... I'm here to ease you, to please you, to treat you right... Girls like Anne are not like me, I'm Kerianne, the girl of your dreams..."

Kerianne? The name of the first girl he'd ever loved. Her tragic fate, and that lovely face... It was all coming back to him!

"You remember, I'm so glad, so cheerful, so chipper! Come with me, Trevor, I miss you... I love you... I want you back..."

Though the familiar outline of this old friend assuaged most of his fears, her ghostly appearance did nothing to calm him down. Why was she dressed for a funeral: a button-down black dress? So eerie...

"Don't you trust me darling, lovie, ...love-you?"

Her voice bound him to her, like a spell, no. Like a dream... The entire world became a dream in the short amount of time he spent with her. The fields of gray turned to open hills of flowers, sunshine, like she used to be. The dark colors of Kerianne still remained, like a shadow on her memory. To be honest, Trevor lost his nerves at the sight. He had to understand her, the sudden reappearance, everything!

"Kerianne, I have missed you, but why are you here? Why have you come for me, taken me out of the rain?"

"The rain plays tricks on us all, dear Trevor, Trev, Trevvie. I might just be another trick... Don't expect much."

Chills. Trevor shivered with the chills he'd never known to come from his Kerianne. What had his mind tricked him into? This woman was obviously not his long lost beloved. Who was she? Why had she claimed to be her? Wait, did he even know her to begin with?!

Trevor's real first love had been named Katty, and she was his first cat. She'd been run over when he was three. He'd never even met a Kerianne before! This girl messed with his memories of life! He had to escape this nightmare...

"Wait, please, I will explain! All you must do is wait, sit, meditate!"

She childishly clutched to his pants leg, and appeared a lot younger than she had before. What was she?

"Please?"

1311211.content:
Anne's car slipped to a halt around the bend in the dirt road. Listening to the wipers swish, squish, smack the icy sludge away from the shield, Anne came to herself. Trevor could be thoughtless, but he wasn't cruel and leaving him in this weather was cruel - something Anne, though selfish, was not. She hooked her right arm about the passenger seat's headrest and looked through the back window for a second or two before really making up her mind.

Hastily pushing the shifter into reverse, Anne backed the car around the bend in the road and then to where she'd left Trevor, but he seemed to have vanished. Leaving the engine running, Anne got out of the car. Hunkering into her coat, she looked around as best she could then started to call for him. She had wandered to the tree line on the right side of the road when she tripped over a log, or what she thought was a log. The log groaned and it took all within Anne to keep from yelping in terror. "Trevor?"

The guy was curled into a ball near one of the pine trees. He seemed to be dozing, but fitfully. Anne could not get over how strange it seemed for him to be asleep in this weather, lying on such soggy ground.

He was muttering a kind of sing-song-y poem that went something like: "No. Go away. No. I can't stay. No. Let me alone. No. I must be gone."

Anne's brow furrowed, but she couldn't determine if he was speaking to her in his strange little rhyme or if he was speaking to someone in his dream, so she grabbed his arm and pulled at it a bit to test his weight. In the sludge, it was reasonably easy to pull him, so that's what she did - Anne pulled Trevor to her car. Getting him into the car took considerably more strength, but she managed that too.

"Now, what to do with you," Anne said, having buckled him into his seat and rounded the car to get in herself.

He was still muttering, mostly nonsense about his cat being called Katty and not Kerianne, his eyes opening now and again, like he was suffering from some fairy tale enchantment or something. Anne leaned over and opened the glove box. From inside, she pulled a big stack of papers and tossed them into the back seat. Then she saw what she wanted - a bottle of caffeine pills. She had used them once or twice to get through an especially boring meeting, but she sure was glad she'd left them in her purse and then transferred them into the borrowed little hatchback. She fumbled around blindly in the back running board and finally pulled out a small travel sized bottle of water with an "Ah-ha!"

Forcing twice the normal dose on the dozing fellow in her passenger seat proved a little more challenging than she'd expected, but eventually the pills had been swallowed and Anne settled back in her seat to wait for them to work. She turned the heater as far to the red as she could with hopes she'd dry out before having to see Paul later. He was going to kill her when he found out that not only had she gotten lost, she'd picked up Trevor. No, Paul wasn't going to be too happy about that.

Trevor groaned but was still in his dream state. Anne put the car into drive and slowly started to make her way through the gloom and towards what she hoped was a main highway. She couldn't remember where he said he needed to go, but she hoped it would be on her way.

"Wait, I've gotta see her!" Trevor sat up straight, his eyes wide.

Anne's brow furrowed but she didn't give him more than a cursory glance. She had to focus on the road, otherwise they'd end up in a ditch.

"What! Where am I?"

"Nowhere important, just in my little car. Where'd ya think you were?"

"I... I can't be here. I've got to see her!"

"Well, unless you wanna hop out of a moving vehicle, I suggest you calm down and wait until we find a decent highway." Anne did some of her own muttering about the state of the road way and how it was all Paul's fault that she was out so late and trying to take a "short cut" that had turned out to not be so short.

Trevor rung his hands, ran fingers through his damp hair; his eyes darted from here to there, and his foot started to pat the floor boards. Anne wondered if she'd really done him a disservice by giving him so many caffeine pills, but it had gotten him out of whatever stupor he had been in.

In the road ahead, she noticed a shadowy figure. A deer maybe? She slowed to an even more labored pace and squinted at the form. Trevor said again he had to see “her” whoever, she was and then…

131121111.content:
"What in tha?!?" Anne exclaimed as Trevor threw his door open and bolted from the car. He was running into the forest and then he was gone from sight. He really didn't want her help, but durn-it, Anne knew she couldn't just leave the boy out in this nasty weather. For a moment she considered her options... and those became less and less as she tarried. "Awe, man!"

Anne leaned over the console to grab a small handgun from the glove compartment. It'd been years since she'd felt she needed it, but tonight strange things were happening and she knew she'd feel better if she had it with her. She checked to make sure the safety was on in the dim dome light and then sticking it in the back of her waistband, she exited the car, leaving it running.

She ran in the direction Trevor had disappeared, thinking all the while how stupid it was that she was running after someone who'd always been more an acquaintance than a friend. She stumbled a little at first as she got acclimated to the rough muddy terrain, but after a bit, she was running swiftly through the forest, scanning from side to side looking for any sign of Trevor. Her training was starting to return and her muscle memory seemed to take over. Anne paused to listen every fifty feet or so, hoping to notice danger before it found her. "No use running into something unawares," her father had always said.

On a small rise ahead, there was a rather large sprawling oak tree. The air about it was unsettling, so Anne paused near, sheltering herself behind a tree to watch and listen. Sure enough, she heard that strange sing-song voice again. Thankfully, it wasn't calling to her, because she couldn't help but be affected by the power in it even from this distance. She peered around the rough pine tree and saw what she'd almost expected to see. A shadowy glowing figure of a woman hovered over Trevor, who had curled up in a snoozing ball amidst the large roots at the base of the old tree. It looked pretty dry under the tree from where Anne stood, but she couldn’t be sure. “Well, here goes nothin’,” she whispered to herself. She palmed the cold gun and snapped the safety off. She knew just how many shots she’d have before she would be in trouble. It was enough. Specter or wood spirit or whatever that thing was had a weak spot, and Anne would find it.

Anne scoped out the trees about the large oak and then pointed the gun. She squeezed the trigger and then she was off. When she made it to the next tree, she aimed and shot another warning shot into the top of the oak. A medium sized branch snapped and fell with a horrific booming crash. Trevor was protected from the debris by the pronounced roots at the base of the tree, but the specter had vanished and Anne couldn’t hear any more of her poisoned song. She wove her way around several times before approaching Trevor, but the shadowy whatever that had been was nowhere to be seen. Trevor still snored in happy slumber, but Anne couldn’t be sure he was alone. She waited in the icy darkness shivering for as long as she thought she could before deciding how to get in there.

She ran. She ran into the dry undergrowth of the tree and slid to a stop beside Trevor. She slapped his cheek, pinched the back of his arm, anything she could think of to wake him, but he was out. Anne rolled her eyes. This guy had turned out to be more trouble than he was worth. She pulled at his arm, hoping she could drag him to the car, but this time, in the dry leaves under the oak tree, she couldn’t manage to budge him more than a few yards before she realized there was no way she’d be able to drag him all the way back to the car, almost a quarter mile away. As an afterthought, she pulled out the gun again, pointed into the ground a ways off and squeezed off a round. Then she pressed the gun barrel’s tip to the back of his arm. That got the desired reaction. He was roused and was fully awake, swearing and rubbing the burn on the back of his arm. Anne just stood there, waiting for him to focus. When he did, she grabbed his hand and pulled him behind her into the forest.

1311211111.content:
Tessa Sherman watched casually from a distance as the woman used the hot tip of her gun to awaken the man. She had absolutely no idea who they were, and why they were out in such fiendish weather, but whatever their reason, it mattered absolutely nothing...starting now. By her side stood Jed, her mysterious aide. The two of them were more than a match for the woman--she had to be almost out of ammunition--and the unconscious man. "Come on," she muttered, jumping off the rock and strolling casually towards the two people.

Jed followed, aware that Tessa was not going to pause to consider the consequences of her actions. Once again, she was merely concentrating on the instinct of hunting that her father, a bounty hunter, had taught her. She had in turn taught Jed, but Jed, coming from a more rule abiding background, practiced more caution. "Tessa, please. Why are these people important?"

"I don't know. They just are." Tessa knew to listen to her soul when it urged her to capture some seemingly random person and hold them hostage. "Look at us. We're in the woods, lost without any way to call for help, weaponless except for our own martial training, and without any form of money." Her eyes coldly pointed out to Jed the truth--everything she said was only too true; there was no way that they could continue mucking around in the forest like this.

"Fine. I concede, but he's awake, and might be a threat." Jed's voice was a whisper, blown away quickly by the wind, but he knew his face told the story clearly enough for Tessa. "Where do you plan to keep them? And we've got to watch for these deceitful sprite-people that got the guy."

Tessa shrugged, then walked up to the woman. "Touche. Hand over the gun and keep your hands visible on that branch."

"What if we don't want to?" The man demanded.

"Trevor. Please. No more trouble." The woman seemed exasperated, and not too close to the man, Trevor. "Here. My car is up on the road."

"A car? My God! Did you hear that?" Jed was excited, as he picked up the gun, worried that if Tessa were to take it, she'd turn serial killer yet again. "We can get out of here."

"But it's probably blown away in this wind," The woman looked around warily. "I don't like it here."

"We didn't choose to be here either," Tessa purred. "I'm Tessa Sherman. I know your companion is Trevor. You are?"

"Anne." The one word answer clearly indicated the woman was unhappy with the situation and unwilling to say anything more. The defiant and harried attitude of Trevor indicated the same.

"Well than," Tessa smirked. "Anne and Trevor. You are going to come with us up to this road and you'll lead us down it towards the nearest civilization, where we will either kill you or be treated royally with free accommodations and new clothes."

"Do we have other options?" Trevor asked, not really wanting to be killed.

"You can come to our cave." Jed put in calmly. "I'm Jed and Tessa didn't mean the first option. Coming to the cave as our hostages is your only option." Angrily, Tessa followed, as rearguard, while he led them towards the cave, gun pointed at them occasionally when he turned around and walked backwards to make sure Tessa didn't try anything dirty. She could get nasty when he forced her to be less murderous.

He knew that when she left, but he had no time to help an attractive stranger. He had to get to the lodge. And it was going to be hell, in this rain and mud.

Trevor turned away from the road and looked at the hill that ascended into the darkness. He knew the lodge was up there. He should be able to see some lights from here. But everything above him was pitch black. That was weird.

He kept staring at the hill, sizing it up, as he strode towards its base. All he could hear was the constant pattering sound of the rain as it slapped the ground. Trevor was in the middle of a thought of what he would do when he finally got to the lodge, when he felt a heavy thud to his back and felt strong arms wrapping around his waist and throwing him to the ground. Trevor's face smeared through a patch of mud, some cold mud splattering onto his front teeth and under his bottom lip.

Trevor's assaulter grabbed his shoulder and whipped him around, slamming his back into the cold, wet ground. As if Trevor wasn't uncomfortable enough before, now he had mud creeping down the back of his underwear. The mysterious attacker straddled him, wrapping an exceedingly strong hand around Trevor's collar and pulling his torso upwards. Trevor let out a painful yell as a large fist crashed into his face, just under his right eye. The fist came down again, this time landing square on Trevor's bottom lip, sending hot blood down his chin. Then his attacker froze one arm cocked back into a threatening punch.

It was dark, unusually dark, but Trevor could make out a heavily stubbled chin, thin lips curled back, exposing slightly crooked teeth, and two eyes that bore the look of a trapped wild animal. He had no idea who his attacker was.

"Who are you," the man screamed, shaking Trevor as he spoke. His voice carried the unmistakable trademark of panic. "Who the hell are you? Tell me! Tell me now! The stranger kept violently shaking Trevor. This guy was out his mind. There was nothing Trevor could say to calm him down. Nothing he could say, could make this better. But he had to try something. He may not have time for a fight.

Trevor stared up at the stranger that sat on top of him, on hand intertwined into his collar, the other cocked back, ready to send another painful punch Trevor's way. Whoever this man was, he was large and had the upper hand. Maybe this guy was psychotic, maybe nothing Trevor said would make a difference. But two things were for certain: He couldn't afford to be beaten to a pulp, and he couldn't afford to waste any time.

"I'm Trevor," he shouted trying to remain calm. Trying to think on his feet. "Trevor, that's all I remember."

"What the hell does that mean," the stranger shouted in a paranoid voice. His fist tightening around Trevor's collar.

"I don't know. I don't know." Trevor voive started to show his anger and confusion. "I woke up this morning in the lodge at the top of this hill. I have no idea how I got there. And it sounds to me that you may be in the same situation. There's someone in that lodge that may know what the hell is going on here, and if I can't get to her, then we're all screwed." Trevor squirmed a bit, his backside was soaked now. He could feel cold chunks of mud sliding down his pants.

"Oh so you're a good guy, huh? You expect me to believe that?" The stranger seemed to be calming down a bit, although his hand was still pulled back, ready to pummel Trevor's face.

"I don't know what I am. Good, bad, or in between. And I don't care. I just have to get to that lodge. Now are you going to come with me and try to make a difference or just beat me into the dirt," Trevor was losing patience. Time was running out. "We have to get up there before sunset. It will be a hell of a lot easier with a tough guy like you helping me out."

Paul dropped his fist and let go of Trevor's collar. He felt like crying. He was in pain, tired, and confused. He also had no idea who the hell he was. He nothing other than his first name. He had no idea who Trevor was. He had no idea where the lodge was. But what else could he possibly lose. Sure, it was possible that Trevor could be lying to try to catch him off his guard. But the risk of that, of anything, had to be better than wandering around these woods like some crazed mad man, attacking strangers just to get some answers.

Paul stood up and extended a hand to help Trevor up. Trevor took Paul's hand and struggled to stand up. Trevor tried to brush some of the mud caked all over his body. He wiped some of the mud smeared on his face and spit the mud from his mouth. He gave Paul a weary look and attempted a smile. He extended a hand towards him.

"How about a formal introduction," Trevor said with a hint of humor to his voice.

"I'm Paul. Sorry about the knocks to the face." Paul detected a smile making its way to his lips. This was the first time since this morning he could remember feeling anything but scared, angry, and confused.

"Don't worry about it." Trevor pointed to the hill that stood about ten yards away. "We gotta climb that to get to the lodge. I hope you're ready."

Paul's smile faded. He was on the verge of complete exhaustion. Now he had to climb that muddy hill into what looked like complete darkness. Great, maybe he should have just beat Trevor into the dirt afterall.

131232111.content:
Trevor wiped some blood from his chin already soaked and soiled sleeve. He was staring towards the base of the hill, with his back to Paul. The surprise beating he took from Paul turned out to be a bit of a blessing. Making it up this hill and sorting through whatever chaos awaited him when he made it to the top would have been a daunting task by himself. Paul seemed a bit of a loose cannon. But Paul was desperate and determined, which could be useful on a night like this.

The rain was pounding down in the thick streams now. The ground below Trevor's feet was starting to flood, causing thick streams of mud hurrying towards lower ground. Which meant the earth would be much softer. Which meant climbing this hill would be a true test of will. Trevor looked up the hill, into the dark night sky. Raindrops fell heavily on his face, washing it clean. He could only see about twenty yards up the hill's steep grassy surface. Several large rocks jutted out of the hill, forming a disordered makeshift staircase. Following the rock path would be the easiest way up the hill, even though it would take longer.

Trevor looked over his shoulder to ready his new companion for the difficult climb. When he looked back, he saw nothing but darkness. He faced the hill again to see Paul's large silhouette lumbering towards the base of the hill. Apparently, Paul was impatient along with being desperate and determined.

Trevor ran to catch up with Paul. He got to the base of the hill just as Paul reached up to grab a large tuft of grass with both hands. Paul grunted as he pulled hard on the grass, attempting to heave himself up the hill.

"Wait, Paul," Trevor shouted. Just then the tuft of grass in Paul's hands lost its grip in the ground and pulled free under the pressure of Paul's weight. Gravity took over and Paul fell backwards with a thud and a splash into a muddy stream at the base of the hill. Paul angrily pounded the muddy ground with a large fist.

"The ground's too wet to use the grass as a hold. We have to follow these rocks as far up as they go. Otherwise we'll just fall on our butts all night," Trevor said, extending a hand to help Paul up. Paul looked up with a hint of a smirk on his stubbly face. He grabbed Trevor's hand and struggled to his feet.

"I guess I should have waited for you," Paul said, his lips widening into a sardonic smile. "You first chief." Paul gestured his hands grandiosely towards the hill, as if he were a butler escorting a guest to a grand feast.

"Alright, follow me as best you can. Stay close and try to keep your feet on the rocks. If we lose each other, just make it up to the top." Trevor carefully stepped onto a large rock about a foot up from the hill's base, placing his hands on the hill's surface to steady himself. He located a second rock and gingerly lifted his feet, one at a time, to stand on the next rock. And he began slowly making his way up the hill in this fashion, carefully finding footholds in the rocks and pushing up the hill with his legs.

Paul stood at the base, watching Trevor climb up the hill. When Trevor was about ten feet up, Paul followed suit, trying to place his feet and hands in the same places Trevor did. He kept his eyes on Trevor, doing his best to follow the same path and keep close to him. Unfortunately, Trevor seemed to be advancing up the hill much faster. Within a few minutes, Trevor was at least thirty feet ahead of him and not slowing down.

Paul's muscles were sore, his lungs heavy with exhaustion. Puffs of steam escaped his mouth as he panted heavily, exerting increasing effort to maintain steady footing and maneuver up the steep hill. He tried to call out to Trevor, to tell him to slow down. But the words came out only as a weak, hoarse whisper. He had no choice, but to keep up at his own pace. Trevor would wait for him at the top.

Paul looked up, searching the hillside for Trevor, but saw nothing except a dark, empty hill. He reached up with a shaking left hand, grasping a small rock. Paul pulled hard on the rock, attempting to heave himself up to another, flat stepping stone.

Suddenly, the rock gripped in Paul's left hand seemed to give, tearing loose from the soft soil it was partially buried in. The rock fell freely down the hill, tumbling and clacking against other rocks on its way down to the base. Paul's balance shifted sharply backwards. His left arm, without a hold began flailing wildly around in the cold air. His right hand instinctively gripped a wad of grass in front of him.

As Paul's weight pulled backwards, the grass gave way, its roots pulling free from the earth. Paul's eyes widened as his body gave in to gravity and he fell down the hill. He let out a raspy whisper-scream as his back thudded against the rock that was formerly his foothold.

Paul's body slammed forcefully and repeatedly against the rocky surface of the hill. He rolled down, sheltering his face and head with his arms, his elbows and forearms slamming into hard earth. Sharp pain exploded in his back as several ribs snapped under the force of gravity and momentum. His legs flew around wildly screaming in pain as they collided with rocks.

Paul's momentum slowed to a slide as he hit the soft mud near the base of the hill. His body went limp as it slid down the last bit of the muddy embankment. With gravity's final tug, Paul's body flipped over to his back in the cold mud. He lay at an awkward angle, his feet aiming diagonally up the hill, his head lying in a puddle at the base. Paul's arms were pointing straight out from his body, making him look like some beat up and disregarded scarecrow.

Paul opened his eyes weakly. His whole body was shaking in pain. Warm blood secreted from abrasions and lacerations on his arms, legs, and torso. A hot pain vibrated through his chest and stomach. His lungs felt like stones. It seemed like all the air had been forced from his body. It felt as if at least two ribs were broken. He had no voice. His mind was overwhelmed with pain. Paul stared silently at the sky as a constant stream of rain poured down to the ground. He couldn't move, he couldn't think. Soon he would be dead. And all he could do was lay in pain and stare at the sky.

"Ellen!" Sinclair yelled, forgetting the people with him, and tore off into the night, his eyes glazed with determination and fear. Fear for his sister.

"Wait! Sinclair!" Anne called in the fading darkness, but the man ignored her, and fought harder to reach Ellen.

He makes stupid jokes about how he's a time traveler, and now he's still making them, but instead meant to hurt him.

But still, he leapt back up and carried on, not even bothering to check his injuries. All that mattered in his mind was Ellen.

The man watched from the trees. The man named Sinclair seemed uncertain. Ellen just stared at him, eagerly awaiting his reply. Gage shivered. It was cold out here, and blinding flashes of lightning tore at the sky. A prong of lightning hit somewhere near. Gage could tell because the thunder--a deafening explosion--followed only seconds later. The light gave off his position. He swore.

"Did you see something?" Sinclair asked.

Ellen was afraid. "What if it's--"

"Shh." Sinclair walked forward, ready for anything, it seemed.

Gage had just wanted to take a walk to clear his mind. Why oh why did he always have to get himself into trouble? "I'm here." He said, not waiting for Sinclair to find him.

The man named Sinclair stopped, but was by no means calm. "Who is it?"

Gage stepped out of the darkness. Sinclair relaxed when he saw him, seeing, Gage was sure, a slim, brown-haired, dark skinned guy in his twenties. Harmless. Average.

Unless, of course, one were to see the multitude of scars on his back where someone had shot him. Gage had been climbing up a rickety brick building at the time, and had fallen about twenty feet to the ground. He was not so innocent as he first seemed, but he'd never hurt anyone, and he hoped Sinclair saw that. Ellen was sizing him up, and she liked what she saw, apparently, since she extended her hand to shake. "Ellen. Who are you?"

"I'm Gage. There's an easier way to get where you want to go, you know. I can take you there."

Sinclair looked suspicious. Ellen thought a while, and nodded. "Anything will help."

So Gage led them. Finally, he got them near the back of the little cottage. "That window leads into a bathroom. The light's broken out. No one will hear you."

"Wait, aren't you coming?"

"I didn't plan on it."

"Why don't you help us? you seem to know your way around." Seeing the uncertainty in his eyes, Ellen hurried to say, "Please?"

Gage finally nodded. Sucker! He thought derisively. Gage, my friend, you are a sucker for a pretty lady.

He flipped agilely into the window, opening and closing it silently as he stepped inside. If there was one gift nature had blessed him with, it was movement. The other two followed. A sound, a crack outside of the bathroom door startled them.

Gage flattened himself against the wall.

13413.content:
The rain pelted the roof of the car as the young woman stared in astonishment in front of her, her eyes wide with fear. She sat there, shaking, as she tried to make sense of what had just happened.

A man had appeared from the forest as she'd fought to get her broken down car running again and, spotting him, asked him if he was okay and if he needed a ride.... That's when it happened. He disappeared. Literally. Anne had seen every terrifying detail. He was standing in front of her car, her head lights shining brightly, as clear as day. She flicked them off for a moment, and then.... nothing. When she switched them back on a heartbeat later, he was gone.

The experience shocked Anne beyond belief. All her life she had been skeptical, and when that suddenly changed and she'd, for the first time, been faced with a thing she has no way for explaining, she no longer felt safe. It was unnatural, and all of her previous beliefs and thoughts were screaming at her that it couldn't be true -- it mustn't be true. There were no such things as ghosts!

And yet...

'I have to get out of here,' she thought. Her mind was reeling and her blood running cold, and as she tried to fidget out of the driver's seat, realized that her hands were shaking, and that her legs were weak with fear.

She grabbed for the door handle, but stopped. 'No,' she thought. 'I can't go out there. It's not safe.' Anne sat there, shaking as she tried to figure out a plan, but her frightened mind couldn't conjore up anything.

The shaky brown haired woman, who was soaked by the rain and was pressed up against her seat, began to cry silently. She was lost, utterly lost, in the middle of the forest in a storm with nothing but her rapidly colding car, and possibly supernatural threats lurking in the shadows. She thought of every horror movie, every paranormal investigation she'd ever watched or read about, and her heart began to pound painfully and her eyes start to dart. Her senses were on high alert, and every little noise seemed to be magnified. Every little sound the dying car made would make her jump, and each little movement from the dark woods would make her whimper in fear.

A few minutes later, when all was quiet once more, Anne let out a scream. A shadow darted across the road in front of her, quick but slow enough to send an icy wave of fear up her spine as she realized that it wasn't a trick of light or a movement made by the wind. It was in the form of a person, and darted across through the night, nothing more than a black shadow.

Tears now streamed down her face as she clung to her seat, her hands gripping the sides till thay paled with blood-loss and shook terribly with the effort. "This cannot be happening, this can not be -- " she let out another shriek, but this time a powerful lungful that raised to a high pitched horror-movie scream. Through the reflection of her rear view mirror, was a man. And he was sitting in her back seat.

But then he was gone, as soon as the girl caught sight of him, but that didn't stop her from catching hold of the handle and pushing the door open, the cold night air spilling in. Adrenaline pulsed through her veins and she was no longer shaking. She was blinded by the instinct for survival. The woman half leapt, half fell out of her car, and bolted away, to the side of the road. There she stopped, unsure of where to go. She glanced back to see if anything was pursuing her, and as she did, her eyes widened to almost impossible size and she stumbled backwards, tripping and hitting the ground hard. Her mouth opened in yet another pleading cry....

But no noise came out. Along with the terrible fear came a calming sensation. Anne knew that the growing sense of awe and ease wasn't created by her. It came like a great force, like the pound of an ocean wave against rocks. She stared up ahead of her as many more shadows materialized from the trees and amongst them, strolled a figure.

"Anne, I have been waiting for you."

The speaker was the most beautiful woman Anne had ever seen. Her voice rang through the night as smooth and gentle as a sigh yet as powerful as a howling wind. Her long platinum hair whispered around her frame as her pale face lifted into a gentle smile. The shadows crowded around her, and as Anne looked closely, could see more clearly the details of them. She could just make out the form of people – men and woman and children, both old and young. Their faces were dark and menacing, and Anne quickly looked away, seeking out the lady’s reassuring gaze.

"Wh-What are you?” Anne asked, swallowing.

The lady ignored that. “If you wish to save the girl, you must follow me.”

Anne blinked. “Sa- Save the girl? What do you mean – ?“

The mysterious woman’s eyes gravened. “There is no time. You must come with me.” And without another word, she turned away and disappeared into the darkened forest, the shadows de-materializing from the road as she passed.

Anne stared back wordlessly. A powerful current of icy rain pelted her side, and she glanced around. She was utterly alone now, and the storm was worsening.

Her thoughts and emotions were a mess as she shakily tried to stand. She did not know what to do… what to think. All she felt was confusion and foreboding, along with uncertainty. She still didn’t know where the heck she was. And what was this about a girl in trouble?

Anne didn’t know what to do, but as a sudden flash of lightening forked from the sky, and thunder clapped in the dark heavens above, she knew that she had to do something.

info.brief_description: A story for your characters to mingle with others.
info.description:
** Image ID #886505 Unavailable **
Image created by Tenea (64)


We all know that building characters is of the utmost importance in fiction. The way they interact with each other tells the reader much about them and helps them to develop.

This is an interactive game for anyone interested in working on developing a character, either one already in development or just a thought you want to explore.

Please follow the following guidelines:

-- Add one or more of your characters to the story. Write from the POV of your own character(s), using the characters and situations from previous chapters.

-- If you have questions about POV, you can check out this brief article: "Who's in Charge Here, Anyway?" 

-- Make sure to list your character's name as part of the chapter title. Add the title behind his/her name.

-- Please remember the ASR rating! Scenes do not need to be graphic in order to get to know your character better.

-- Feel free to put your character into different parts of the story to further test her/his abilities to react with others.

-- Chapters exceeding the rating will be deleted.

Enjoy!



Thank you to whoever nominated Become Your Character!
